so began reading for a bit. Morning came and I was hungry and thirsty. I searched around the neighbourhood for supplies and came across a packet of cigarettes and some peanut butter. I ate the cigarettes and the peanut butter and sipped some more toilet water. I also found a backpack and various other supplies. I went on a journey north. My mood seemed to change as I smashed Z after Z' head in. My depression lifted and I found new vigour. As the day went on I looted a liquor shop for crisps and ice-cream and broke into a farm house to steal a hammer and nails.

....that's pretty much how my game went so far.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm a huge fan of true survival games, like don't starve. where it's hard to survive and, if possible at all, even harder to thrive. During the winter sale I was looking for a new survival game to play, and this always proves to be a difficult task because there are so many fake survival games, games that with enough grinding you can easily thrive.

So I decided to give project zomboid a try, and the game positively surprised me.
It is a really hard game where if you be careful enough, you'll be able to survive, but a minor screw up can and will kill you. Wasn't prepared for that zombie in the bathroom of a house you thought was empty? He can scratch you or bite you, giving you a high chance of zombification, an illness with no cure in the game. Yes, you a zombie manages to scratch or bite you, there's a big chance that the game over timer will start ticking.
And even if you isolate yourself from the huge amounts of zombie in the forested areas of the huge (HUGE) map, you'll still will have to deal with food and water. Food can be preserved for more time in fridges, but guess what? After a random amount of days, the power will be cut out. You can drink water from sinks and toilets, but just like the power, water will also be cut out after a random amount of days.

The character creation is fantastic as well, and the trait system reminds me of old fallout games. You have good and bad traits that give you negative and positive points, respectively. You can only start the game if you have 0 or more points so you'll need to balance your character accordingly.

And it has multiplayer! I had loads of fun playing with two people, scavenging the city for supplies, reinforcing a place to call home...

And finally, another thing that really surprised me was the amount of zombies in the game. Depending on your luck and area in the game, you can stumble upon hordes and hordes of zombies. This feels just like the walking dead, and in fact it's one of the games that feels most like the series, apart from the telltale's ones, of course.

This game is still in early access and it's loads of fun. I can't even think of how it will look and play when it's done.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been looking for a zombie survival game for years- a good one. Something I could play for awhile, something that wouldn't leave me feeling like there could be 'more'a. I remeber the first time I heard of H1Z1, and DayZ- they both sounded amazing. Looking at screenshots, how could I not be impressed?

How naive. If you really look around for any zombie apocalypse games, those two names are bound to come up, and with them, their history of major, major disappointment.

A couple days ago, I was looking through my Steam Queue, and Project Zomboid happened to pop up. Watching the video, I was intrigued. Yeah, the graphics weren't photorealistic, but then again, when did they ever have to be? When I looked towards the reviews and comments, I was estatic, and could only hope it measured up.

It totally did.

I've only played a few hours as of this review, but I'm absolutely hooked. In its current state, it is completely playable, and worth its $14.99 price tag.

Pros
- Realistic survival simulation

Death comes swift and quick for those who don't pay enough attention. From basic survival needs like food and water, the game goes beyond and even throws in challenges in other forms. Staying out in the rain might get you sick, and if you don't take care of that, you might be visiting the Grim Reaper pretty soon. You can be cold, scratched, bitten, and you can bleed, and feel nausea and so much more. Honestly, you get screwed over pretty quick

- Good UI

Not much to say. It's got clean menus, and useful graphics.

- Good Personalization

Do you love zombie games? Do you still suck at killing them? No worries. This game has quite a few different play styles, each one taking place at a different time in the apocalypse. The Initial Infection (a non-canon play for those of us who suck at the games we love), The First Week (where things start to pick up, and those zombies really start to pay closer attention to you), Six Months Later (the name says it all, but you better know how to get water for yourself...), and the last mode, Survival, where you see how long it takes you to die.

The first three modes even have more difficulty options within them, so you really get to pick what type of game you want to play.

-  The fact that this is only Early Access

This game feels full, alive (or, uh, undead?), and pretty complet minus some bugs here or there. The fact that this game will only get better is really exciting!

Cons
- Melee/ selection dificulties

By no means rendering the game unplayable, but melee is always the way I go. This could just be my game, but I occasionally have issues with fighting zombies. I'll be aimed right on them, but whatever weapon I'm beating them with will move right through them. Moving around a bit usually helps this, but it can be an ocasional annoyance.

-  Cooking is burdensome

Not something that is super problematic, but still worth mentioning. Some players have found cooking to be a hit and miss problem without the help of the wikia or other guides. Recipes, unless you know them, can leave you confused on what you can and can't cook. Yeah, you can make soup. But, no, you can't make bowls of cereal and milk (which I know from my own tragic expirience).

Conclusion or tl;dr
The problems in Project Zomboid are very minimal, and are not enough to turn a player away from the game. What you get with this a really fun game that you can play for hours on end. Whether you want to build a fort, or leech off existing houses, live in a Zombie-filled city, or a blank country side, you're in charge of your own tragic and inevitable death.

It's fifteen bucks of sign-me-the-♥♥♥♥-up. If you wanna see how you'd fair in the zombie apocalypse, here's your game

Pluss the mascot is a raccoon. A cute raccoon. Who doesn't love trash pandas?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been very interested in this game for a long while. It was shaping up to be the zombie survival game I've always wanted. After playing it for the first time, I fell in love. It had the right amount of depth and realism needed to really make it special. You had to deal with all the struggles of surviving in a zombie outbreak, from not getting eaten alive by the zombies themselves to depression. The game also has a good amount of difficulty, even if the game is easy to learn and master after multiple playthroughs. Surviving for a skilled player becomes trivial. That's where the NPCs come in though, to spice up the playthrough.

And that's the reason why I am not able to recommend this game, unfortunately. I understand the NPCs the devs had planned were very ambitious (probably too ambitious for a small team) and need time to get right. I also understand that the devs have went through development hell, and that's also part of the reason for NPCs not being close to finished. However, it's been about 6 years since I started following this game, and I'm beginning to give up hope of ever seeing NPCs in this game anytime in the near future.

For me, NPCs are a big component of this game, and not having them just makes the game seem hollow. Sure, you have all this depth to this survival experience, but it's really hard to have the motivation to survive if you have nothing to survive for. I feel like NPCs are what would take this game and really turn it into something special. Unfortunately, the devs have decided not to reveal anything about NPCs until they are in their final phases of development. While I understand why they are doing this, it is causing many people who follow this game (me included) to lose hope of ever seeing NPCs in the game.

However, there is multiplayer. If you are the type of player who loves multiplayer survival games, then go ahead and pick this game up. It works very well from what I've played of it. However, I personally am a singleplayer fan, and so NPCs are what makes or breaks this game for me. Unfortunately, until NPCs are added (or we get any news about it in the upcoming months) I cannot recommend this game for anyone who isn't wanting to play multiplayer. While it is fun for a bit, the singleplayer will get old rather quickly.

My biggest fear is that they will start to focus exclusively on multiplayer rather than NPCs. I really hope this is not the case, as I've always wanted a good singleplayer zombie survival experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What can I say?  This game's interface looks so simplistic by today's standards, and yet the Indie Stone team has managed to possibly create one of the best post-apocalyptic zombie survival games in existence to date.

In a sea of games set in the rapidly-becoming-trite-and-humdrum End Of The World By Way Of Zombies scenarios, this one outshines them all.  Yes, even in its alpha stage.

In the sandbox game, you create your character and are greeted with the cheery messages telling you, basically, that you're *going* to die.  There's no rescue coming, the end isn't just nigh, it's done come and gone.  You're on your own.  Your goal is basically just to survive as long as you can.  And die you will.  Many, many times, at least unti you get the hang of the game's mechanics and how to avoid becoming some poor deceased fast food worker's lunch.  Barricade windows and doors, erect walls, keep yourself fed and watered, and don't let your character get bored and depressed.  Flee town and start a farm to live off the land, or hole up in an abandoned warehouse and periodically raid the surrounding buildings for supplies, all while avoiding the relentless horde which believably reacts to sight, sound, and smell.

For those of you used to games like Left 4 Dead, taking on a horde of fifty zombies with a shotgun is one of the worst things you can do in this game.  The noise brings every zombie in a five mile radius bearing down on you, and your ammo supply is typically very limited.  Even one zombie hiding in that corner you forgot to check is a threat.  Whoa, there was one in the tall grass you didn't see, and he wasn't dead.  Now he's gnawing on your ankle.  Whoops, is that a bite?  Welp.  You're infected.  Expect to live another couple of days in game before turning.  Or you could just chug that bottle of bleach you found in the bathroom earlier to end it now...

In short, this game delivers one of the most intense and gripping presentations of the zombie apocalypse I've seen in a video game yet.  Pessimistic and gritty, and incredibly addicting, even without the option of mowing down hundreds of cannon fodder corpses.  I've probably logged more than 150 hours in this game in total, and I still can't get enough.

The best part is that the development team is still working hard, cranking out more and more updates, polishing features, ironing out the bugs, and keeping their players informed about what's to come.  This game is well, WELL worth the $15 they're asking for.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At first glance this game looks relatively simplistic, a simple art style in a sandbox zombie game. But this game has incredible depth. Managing your various states whether you are hungry or thirsty, in a state of panic or anger, wet or overheated, encumbered, sleepy, sick and much much more.

This game is tough, the procedural generation makes each play through unique and can be your best friend or your worst enemy. You might load into a house with an axe and a pistol or you could be heading out armed with a spoon or fork and this is what makes this game great.

Each game feels like a real survivors story, you are not a hero, you are just trying to stay alive as long as you can before meeting your untimely demise.

I am excited for future development of this game and the new features promised look to improve this great game even further.

As for the bad, my only current complaint is the multiplayer system. Hosting a server is a nightmare to do and a server tool or using steam would greatly improve this issue aside from that I am enjoying the game and hope they create a better multiplayer option soon.

From all the zombie survival games I have ever played, this one hits most aspects I hoped for the genre. The goal of the game is simple, you must get from being a survivor to a rebuilder of a one-man society. You are on a time limit as the utilities will soon shut down within weeks, so you must quickly locate your pernament base and fortify it, then start building a garden and several rain catcher barrels to produce food and water. Melee weapons are more important than firearms, and fire can cause a little more destruction than necessary. The zombies, of course, can see, hear, and smell you, so cover up the windows and stick to the shadows and downwind to avoid detection. Remember that a single bite or scratch, even if it is disinfected and bandaged, will strike you ill and kill you no matter what, so don't be cocky and decide to take on an entire herd unless you have a stronghold to take shelter for your dramatic final stand.

The goal for me is always the same. Once the game is started, I quickly go out and search for a suitable shelter or stay in the one I have spawned in. Then I shelter-in-place, you know, cover up all the windows and such. I take inventory of my food, then one everything is situated, I go out into the industrial areas of the map to locate three things: An axe, a saw, a hammer, and lots of nails. The idea is to get an axe to chop down the many confiers that grow in the game world, then use the saw to turn them into wooden planks, then use those planks to build walls, doors, and all sorts of useful furniture to hold your important gear. Once the structure of the base is established, I started fixing up a garden. Sometimes I have to move dirt around, usually up on the roof where I don't have to worry about zombies trampling on my crops. I also build my kitchen outdoors, using a campfire as a stove. With the power and water lines being finite resources, it is imperative to get your self-sufficient base established as soon as possible.

If you are wondering there are vehicles in this game, then the answer is no, there is no planes, trains, and automobiles in Project Zomboid. Your own two feet is your way in moving around the map. Due to the nature of the game engine, I do not expect to find vehicles in this game anytime soon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Found an abandoned house in the forest after marching through the rain for what seemed like hours. The warmth of the fire from the stone helped me calm my nerves as the moans of the undead could be heard not far from where I was. I checked the cabinets for food. No luck. I checked the fridge. Nothing. There had to be something in this place. If the dead didn't get to me, starvation would. Finally, after searching the entire house, I found a bag of chips underneath the couch in the living room. They were the best stale chips I've had in what felt like days. For the very first time, I felt like everything was going to be alright, until I noticed the curtains in the living room window were still open, and the undead had spotted me. Their moans attracted more of them as they began to surround the house, smashing through the windows. Me, with my trust crowbar ran into the bathroom, fearing that this was the end. I closed the door behind me and frankly searched for a way out. Panic settled in as the realization that I had no way out with the undead banging at the bathroom door sank in.
I didn't survive 20 minutes after starting the game. 10 out of 10.
For a game that's only in Early Access and has come this far makes me proud to play it. This is truly what an Early Access release should look like. It can only go up from here.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is how you died.

The entirety of the game is how you died. There is a mystery as to why the zombie outbreak occurred, and you might even find some answers before you die. Ultimately though, Project Zomboid does not represent an against-all-odds struggle where you overcome the undead. Instead, after dying, every subsequent playthrough just lets you survive a little longer, do a little better, and  learn a little more.

Death can come in many, many ways. You have to manage needs, similar to The Sims . You need to eat, sleep, and even need to rest your legs if you're running around too much . You aren't able to see meters that indicate your exact state, but moodlets will appear to let you know exactly what your character is thinking or feeling at any given time. Injuries are common, so if you're scratched or bitten by a zombie, you better tend to them quickly.

The town is populated by other survivors and looters, some just as desperate as you. Everyone is  scared by the thousands of zombies roaming the city, and a looter just might find you and put a shotgun round in your chest as he takes your food and other supplies. Scripted events like this will keep you on your toes, but with every failure comes the chance to prepare a little better for next time.

The zombies themselves are the slow and lumbering kind. You can fairly easily outrun them, but they are legion, and don't easily forget. They are attracted by blood and noise, and all it takes is a single mistake to advertise your location to the horde. You've never had to think in so many different directions and cover your butt in so many different ways before. As a result, every moment is exciting because you never know what lurks around the corner and whether you missed that one thing that will give away your position. Getting into a routine and locking down your safehouse will be just as important as finding food and scavenging for weapons.

Crafting is also a large part of Project Zomboid. At the moment, your character already knows" the recipes needed to create objects to help him: combining a can opener
recommended: and a pot results in a big pot of edible soup
hoursPlayed: for example. Cooking will eventually be part of the game as well
voteText: adding another layer of complexity to basic survival; after all
helpfulPercent: you don't want to be suffering from food poisoning due to eating undercooked meat if you're being chased down by zombies.\n\nOverall
votesHelpful:
well worth a buy. It's easy to see that Project Zomboid has potential and lots of merits.

Recommended
Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Brilliant zombie game. Blends survival, (real survival) action, simulation, RPG mechanics and of course, zombies. While the zombie genre has been over used to death, (just like that pun) this game really brings something fresh. The greatest aspect is the certainty that you WILL DIE. The real question is when.

Graphics
The graphics are pleasing for me, the style mixes really well and nothing ever sticks out of place except bugs in the art and lighting. The developers are costantly working on this though.

Map
The map is set out realisticly and has many locations including lumber yards, farms, wilderness, houses, shops, motels, and more. It is important to mention here that the world is NOT procedurally generated. I think this is good because it makes the world feel far more real and considering how big the developers plan the world to be - it's not going to be a problem.

Gameplay
If you love survival games, this game will be perfect for you. You can play heaps of different ways and even allows for the run and gun" tactics which will definitly lead to an untimely end. The developers do stress that if you want to survive long term

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I normally hate zombie survival games, but I love this one. The devs are working hard to improve the gameplay, and update often enough. Most importantly, for those of you who are looking to opt in during early access, the game is not only playable, but very fun. While not feature complete, it could be released as is and be a perfectly solid, complete game. This is an example of early access done right.

As for the specifics of why this game is worth a buy (at any stage of its development), it has a lot going for it in terms of gameplay. It feels desperate, and it's tough as nails, but you never feel like you got screwed randomly. You're in control of how much risk you take on in your endeavors, and with increased risk comes greater reward. Scavenging in a mall may be far more lucrative than in a trailer park, but there are far more zombies in a mall, for instance.

It's unlike other survival games in that it isn't all about endlessly spamming crafting, though crafting does play a vital role. It's not like other zombie games in that the zombies are actually what made zombies cool 25-30 years ago (as opposed to lame and played out in 2015). They're terrifying in numbers, but are a total joke individually. That said, a moment of negligence could end your life.

You won't regret buying this, and now that Steam offers easy refunds, why not give it a go? It's potentially a classic in the genre. You'd be cheating yourself if you passed this up.

Early Access Review

One of the best survival games out there. It's a fantastic game as-is and definitely worth the price, and yet the potential of this game is vast.

Don't be deterred by the dated graphics of project zomboid. What it lacks in graphic definition it easily makes up for in gameplay and content. In fact I consider the simple graphics a boon to the game, giving ease for developers and modders to add droves of great content.

The only thing that would make this more realistic is a Crapped Your Pants! moodlet, which I assure you would be the first one that would actually happen to me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What can I say about Project Zomboid ?  I love this game.

It's hard to survive in the zombie apocalypse but everything starts to make sense and you start to feel comfortable.
You gather food supplies and barricade a house, your skills are building up.
Everything is fine, then you're checking a house and you casually open a bathroom door and go in without looking and . .
There's three zombies in there that munch or your arm before you can get away.
You put a ripped sheet on it to stop the bleeding but it get's infected because the bandage wasn't disinfected.
Over 2 days you get weaker and weaker and then you die.

This is just one of the many deaths I've had in this game.
If you buy this game, your character will die too and that's the fun !
It's not about whether you die or not, it's about what you did while you were alive.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is easily one of the most addicting I've ever played. Despite some of the major, teeth-grinding glitches, it is very fun.  The game description is essentially what it says; it's a zombie apocalypse simulator. If you loot a house, it's gonna stay empty. If you die with loads of loot at your safehouse, it's going to stay there until your new guy can find it again.
The game also adds a great challenge to its survival aspect. It's not like traditional zombie games like Dead Rising where you can kill 500 zombies within five minutes. I get nervous when I'm up against more than two. You know how in the movies when a character is bitten, and then they turn? That's exactly what happens in Project Zomboid. One bite is all it takes for you to lose the character you've spent the last couple of hours leveling up.
Despite the many, many bugs in this game, it's a great idea and it provides endless hours of fun, scavenging and zombie-slaying!

8.5/10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nhave you ever thought about dying in terrible ways? maybe you feel like starving to death? or maybe you'd like to die from exposure to the elements? perhaps you'd like to be ripped apart limb from limb by a pack of undead flesh eating kentuckians? maybe you'd like to set fire to a house and stand inside as the flames engulf you? if none of those options suit your tastes, fret not! there are plenty of other ways to die in this game. perhaps you aren't entirely sold on dying just yet? wonderful! before you die, there are a plethora of activities to fully engross you: smash windows on houses and local business establishments, litter in the streets with no repercussions, smash the face off your former neighbor with a sledgehammer, make and enjoy a tv dinner, drink water from toilet bowls, or maybe just draw some doodles to pass the time. you can do all of that, and more, but you'll probably just keep dying.

Pros
Captures the survival feeling more than any <survival> out there.
Stunning sountrack and sound effects overall
Killing zombies is so fun you wont get enough

Overall,the best SURVIVAL horror game available out there hands down,and i have played a LOT of survival horror games since its my fav genre 9.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are many things I love and hate about this game.
Allow me to start off with the things I love
.New and fresh concept
.interesting gameplay
.sharp controls
.simplicity
Now the things I hate
.limited features
.limited items
.limited weapons
.lack of more advanced options
.no access to the steam workshop
.clipping issues
.layer issues
It is a very good game concepts but provided me with little to do. I started up the game and was greated by a mess of tabs and menus. After sorting it out I began to play the game with default features. I immediatley found the things I needed for the rest of my playthrough. 67 canned soup and beans, a plethora of weapons and ammo, all the medical supplies that I could find, a saw and hammer with 9 boxes of nails, and a large hiking bag I found on a corpse. I was all set. I found a storage warehouse and barricaded every window and a perimeter fence around the 20 block area of it. I made a large farm that provides me with more tomatoes and potatoes I can eat. I wound up forgetting about the zombies for day 22-34 and was shocked to see a shambler inside of a zippos pizzarea. I was almost longing for a  way to attract the snackers, walkers, biters, ect to my base.
The over all experience was so-so. I have high hopes for this game in the future. hopefully I wont have to settle on burning houses with dead rats in the oven.

Early Access Review

There are many things I love and hate about this game.
Allow me to start off with the things I love
.New and fresh concept
.interesting gameplay
.sharp controls
.simplicity
Now the things I hate
.limited features
.limited items
.limited weapons
.lack of more advanced options
.no access to the steam workshop
.clipping issues
.layer issues
It is a very good game concepts but provided me with little to do. I started up the game and was greated by a mess of tabs and menus. After sorting it out I began to play the game with default features. I immediatley found the things I needed for the rest of my playthrough. 67 canned soup and beans, a plethora of weapons and ammo, all the medical supplies that I could find, a saw and hammer with 9 boxes of nails, and a large hiking bag I found on a corpse. I was all set. I found a storage warehouse and barricaded every window and a perimeter fence around the 20 block area of it. I made a large farm that provides me with more tomatoes and potatoes I can eat. I wound up forgetting about the zombies for day 22-34 and was shocked to see a shambler inside of a zippos pizzarea. I was almost longing for a  way to attract the snackers, walkers, biters, ect to my base.
The over all experience was so-so. I have high hopes for this game in the future. hopefully I wont have to settle on burning houses with dead rats in the oven.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I've gone through a few zombie games, the ones where you can update weapons like you are an engineer, where you can fight like a soldier, survive like Bear Grylls and are basically as inhumane and courageous as one of Daenerys' unsullied.

But I have always wanted to play a true zombie survival game and when I heard about Project Zomboid I decided to give it a go. Needless to say I died on my first day by stumbling in a hoard and thinking that with my flimsy butter knife I would kill them all. I died.. but I was excited.

I realized that it's a different type of game, one where survival of the fittest is the phrase of the day. So like any excited person, after dying a few times I decided to check out youtube videos, improve and learn and then I gave it another go.

It is an amazing game and I am proud to say I've survived 3 weeks already, I have an axe, a saw, lots of needles and a loooot of AMBITION. However, if you do decide to play this game just remember: This is how you're going to die!""

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is easily one of the most addicting I've ever played. Despite some of the major, teeth-grinding glitches, it is very fun.  The game description is essentially what it says; it's a zombie apocalypse simulator. If you loot a house, it's gonna stay empty. If you die with loads of loot at your safehouse, it's going to stay there until your new guy can find it again.
The game also adds a great challenge to its survival aspect. It's not like traditional zombie games like Dead Rising where you can kill 500 zombies within five minutes. I get nervous when I'm up against more than two. You know how in the movies when a character is bitten, and then they turn? That's exactly what happens in Project Zomboid. One bite is all it takes for you to lose the character you've spent the last couple of hours leveling up.
Despite the many, many bugs in this game, it's a great idea and it provides endless hours of fun, scavenging and zombie-slaying!

8.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Once upon a time this was a wonderful game. You'd spawn in a random house in a huge map, scavenge the immediate area, spend a few in game months building a giant fortified compound before eventually getting bored, and then close out a wonderful experience with a glorious firearm rampage through the town center.


The last few updates took the wind out of the sails.

Carpentry skills were rebalanced in such a way that fortified compound building requires the player to grind out way more walls and barricades than any decent sized compound would need just to build up the skill to put a scavenged door in.

Game difficulty is either face rollingly easy or wake up to a sea of zombies on your porch every morning annoying with no sweet spot.

Firearms aren't fun and don't even function as a panic button. Accuracy sucks at low levels and takes ages to skill up, shotguns can only take out 3 zombies max and that's only likely when firing into a huge crowd, and each shot fired will bring in zombies crazy quick and from long distances. Any situation where discharging a firearm seems like a good idea is a situation already lost.

Cars and NPCs will supposedly be implemented at some point (when they're done!) But for now, it just seems as if the game is being balanced for features that don't exist yet and it's not as fun as it once was.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Project Zomboid is one of those games that have great potential. The community of the game is great and the developers are very active. I have been following this game for a very long time now. I believe I bought this game in 2011 before it came out via Early Access on Steam. Every Monday the Developers update their blog telling us what's new in their development and sometimes showing us videos of what's new.

Anyways, down to the gameplay. Now obviously, this game is in Early Access. But, some bugs are quite hard to find in the stable branch. So the game is very much playable. When you first start out playing this game you will probably die much faster than veteran players(unless you're me). But, after awhile you will learn how things work and be able to build a safehouse and even have yourself an efficient farm without having much fear of the zeds trying to kill you. There is also multiplayer! Sadly though, the multiplayer is a bit buggy in a few ways(mostly the zeds). But it is very much playable.

Project Zomboid is a very good game even being Early Access. The developers are active and the community is great. There is much planned for it, and it definitely deserves the try.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've bought this game back when it was in Pre-Alpha, and even back then I didn't regret buying, even though back then there was hardly anything to do. But hell, I loved the game back then, and I still do, if it comes to any zombie survival games - this is it. None other game recreates such tactical thinking, such fear of dying as this game does, every step you make you think about the consequences, you think about where you should set your base, and what to do to protect it best, but what made this game even better was for me was the addition of MP, I've waited since alpha for the game to have Multiplayer added to the game, and I always felt like it would change the game completely, and hell, it did. Multiplayer, especially with friends, added this serious survival feel I didn't feel ever before in a game, not in DayZ, nor Rust, nor any multiplayer survival game. You care for your friend in-game, you don't want them to get injured, or worse - bitten, but you also don't want them standing, doing nothing. As a good example, I'd like to share this survivor's story:

We all assigned roles to what we'll do, one would take care of the food, another would secure the area of zombies, every once in a while we'd send out people to look for supplies, it was amazing, however, while we grew bigger, we needed better supplies, as well as some shotguns, so we decided to go to West Point, we left our home behind, hoping that we'd come back to it still being in shape...Well, at least most of it.  On the way there one of our friend's condition was getting worse - if we wouldn't find medication, he probably wouldn't make it. On the way there, we tactically dealt with zombies, or sneaked through them,  when the odds were too high, I'd fire a couple of rounds to distract a crowd of zombies, we'd get supplies at a drive-by diner and kept going, but unless we hurried - our friend wasn't going to make it, and sadly, he didn't, and it meant more than in any game, and that, is what I'd call a true survival experience. You cared that your friend died, with that one less man, not only do your possibilities go down, but so do your chances go down, every bullet you take, took and will take will make an impact, and a brilliant idea done poorly will cause the death of your team, and this is what I love about the game. While playing it, I felt like I was in some weird mix between The Last Of Us, The Walking Dead and something like Fallout, as amazing as it might be...However, I really think that there should be more of a 'leveling' system, since, even though you do have a bunch of skills to level, if you die, you quickly shake it off, I hope that the devs add something that would make you more attached to your character than you are now.

Project Zomboid is packed with features and things to do and a lot of places to go to, there are a ton of items, and a ton of items to craft, but some currently don't have any use, as mentioned, this game is still fairly early in the development, some features that aren't in the game may be fairly important to survival, for example, a generator, that you'll need to get electricity from when the power runs out, luckily water barrels are buildable, so you won't dehydrate when you run out of water. But those are some things to keep in mind.

The game is very stable right now, there are a few bugs, which is to be expected, considering the game isn't finished, but I'd recommend this game to anyway, since this game is made purely from passion and talent, and it has to be one of my favourite survival singleplayer games, and one of the best (if not the best) of survival multiplayer games, and it ain't even finished yet!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Honestly, I originally found this game quite bland. My fondest memory was spawning in the house, finding and drinking bleach, walking out of the house and then falling over dead. I didn't play it too much after that.

BUT, they recently unleashed online test to the public, at which point my friend immediately set up a server for us and we were away on our adventure. As I am typing this, we have been playing for a solid 3 hours, many notable moments being burning down several houses, barricaded a warehouse, and having friends go out scavenging for supplies while I cooked at home. This is the game that many zombie survival games tried to be (Such as DayZ, which contrary to popular belief was developed long after this game was started). This game gets all of the feels that a zombie survival game should. Instead of immediately searching for weapons to kill zombies with, you always have thoughts in the back of your head as to: Will we have enough food? Will we have time to cook some good food to keep everyone from getting depressed? Did I turn the stove off?

While playing, our favorite thought was having a server that would be able to run 200 players at the same time. Think of the communities that would start with the fact that you can build walls and even houses from scratch, and with the proper tools you can tear down other houses for supplies. Needless to say, I have never been more excited for the future of a single game until now. I feel that anyone who likes tense survival with friends should play this game. This game is, as all 4 of us agreed, is DayZ done right.

TL:DR DayZ but not rushed, with similar ideas of Fallout and The Sims.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I very much recommend this game for anyone who:

a) Likes tense, realistic zombie games;

b) Wants a game that feels more like a movie (i.e. Dawn of the Dead) than dynasty warriors (i.e. Dead Rising);

c) Doesn't mind a game being unpolished (e.g. currently no NPCs in the build I am playing).

The game is extremely compelling, even if a little thin on the ground for content.  You must grit your teeth and carve out some space for your character to call 'home'.  Barricade the doors, shut the curtains, create a sheet rope to access the second floor window.  Then get building your perimeter wall and planting your crops.  Don't forget rain collectors.  Now you have the basics of survival, you can make forays into the dangers of the city, staying in cleared out houses along the way and making sure to attract as little attention as possible.

This game has the potential to leave a huge, huge indent on future zombie games, probably the same way DayZ has already done.  When NPCs and multiplayer are added (especially LAN which would be incredible), this could become the FTL of the zombie genre.

Considering I have got 30 hours of fun from this game, I would say that it's definitely worth £5.  In terms of £10, it's your choice: either wait until the game is a little more advanced and REALLY get your value, or jump in and support the developers early on and enjoy running around a town full of 4500 zombies with no NPCs.

Right now I would rate this game a compelling 7/10 but it has the potential to hit 9 or 10/10.

For reference here is how I rate other non-arcade zombie games:

Resident Evil 4: 9/10
TellTale Games The Walking Dead: 8.5/10
Left 4 Dead: 8.5/10
Resident Evil 2 or 1: 8.5/10
Left 4 Dead 2: 7.5/10
Dead Island: 7/10
Dead Rising: 7/10
The Last of Us: 7/10
DayZ (currently): 6/10 (with the potential to be much higher)
Dead Rising 2: 5/10

As you can see I have left a space at the top for 9.5 and 10/10.  Reason being there has never actually been a zombie game that lives up to the tension, excitement and cloying exigency for survival that permeates the finest zombie movies.

Project Zomboid does have a chance to reach that level or somewhere near it.  The fact that the merest scratch can but not necessarily will turn you eventually into a zombie is a welcome change to the superhero melee murder spree that many other zombie games offer.  The fact that you can die of hunger, thirst, regular disease and being soaked to the bone by freezing rain adds tension.  Your crops can die of diseases, a horde of zombies can shamble up to your safehouse and lay siege to it.  Firing your gun attracts three times as many zombies as you originally intended to engage.

So there you have my take on this charming, albeit incomplete, little game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have played this game offline for over 100 hours.

Listen, all these zombie games do something right. Zomboid, does a lot of things right, but if they aren't what you're looking for, you may not like this game.

This game Is NOT a FPS death match with enough gun types to overthrow a small slavic nation.
This is a game about a random, everyday Kentuckian that got caught up in the zombie appocolypse.

If you like zombies and you like serious, intense survival, this game is for you.
As it is right now, this game offers challenges that will frustrate you and keep you on your toes.
There is the threat of Zombie Hordes, sickness, starvation and making that one freaking mistake that makes you start over.
Play this game if you want a true challenge and actually feel like you accomplished something when you survive a few months.

But what really makes this game worth buying is the potential it has.

The map is already huge and they are going to make it even bigger. They are going to add Metro Louisville into the game map which will be incredible.

The crafting system keeps getting better and they are adding more and more customization.

NPCs and Cars are coming at some point and will take this game to cult-classic type levels on par with Crusader Kings 2 but for zombies.

Buy this game. Be patient. Learn2Play and enjoy!

Even if you buy it now and wait till NPCs come out, it will be worth it. Potentially one of the greatest games in it's niche even as it stands now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the best zombie simulator I've ever played.

Try not to be bitten.
Fortify a building that most likely be your safe house till death.
Loot nearby buildings.
Grow your own potatoes.
Kill every zombie within 1000 feet away from your safe house.
Annihilate hordes by firearms.
Survive as much as possible.

Pros:
- Craft
- Drowsiness
- Farming
- Fortification
- Hunger
- Real survival
- Skills
- Thirst
- Weather
etc.

Cons:
- Isometric 2D graphic

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hands down the best zombie survival game i have ever seen.
The map is still under progress, but it's already huge with two major towns , and many factories / hidden places.
The zombies are really well coded, and everything is taken into account : the noise you make, if you are visible through a window, if they see light inside a building, ect...
Also, your character can only see what's in front of him, you thought you'd have a nice, aerial view of every danger around ? Nope.
The variety of items that can be found is huge, it makes the game very realistic, and scavenging all the more interesting.
The weapon system is made in a way that you can't kill many zombies easily, so it's vital to establish strategies like catching the attention of zombies to get them away from your shelter, and loose them by running between trees.
The graphics are great, the game is light and will run on most computers.

This game is everything DayZ (and many other similar games) should have been, and it keeps getting better with every update, thanks to the awesome Devs.

Did i forget to mention it ? This game is very hard. You're going to die. Quickly.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Probably the best example of appropriate direction for a zombie apocalypse survival game.  Bleak and ominous, emphasized by the game's beautiful musical soundtrack.  Loss of character for failure helps drive a sense of permanence and weight to the world, a trait decidely lacking in most other titles.

However, the environments are largely bland and uninteresting.  The basic mechanics are relatively easy to master, and the game offers no escalation in challenge.  The UI is clunky at best, often feeling needlessly cumbersome.  It attempts to employ RPG elements in the way of independently leveling skills, but then perplexingly ties them back to a master level.

Fun for a bit, but quickly runs out of things to show.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Игру заприметил еще на старте разработки. Подкупающей была тематика (ещё не заезженная на тот момент), пиксель-арт и, конечно же – изометрия. На данный момент это стильный и действительно интересный симулятор выживания на фоне зомби-апокалипсиса. И вовсе не только лишь потому, что изометрия и пиксельная графика. Игра обладает определенным шармом и без этого. Хотя бы на уровне своих возможностей. Будучи небольшой по размерам и миниатюрной в исполнении, игра оставляет за собой многие новинки из Early Access (далее по тексту EA).

В большинстве игр подобной тематики вы оказываетесь в декорациях, которые служат подстилкой для массированного PVP, где, в общем и целом, кроме него заниматься нечем. Мало кто прорабатывает «изнанку мира» (англ. background). В PZ подноготная рядом. Есть два небольших городка где-то в американской глубинке, фермы, поселки и леса. Существует даже карта на манер Google-карт созданная каким-то умельцем. Она позволят оценить размах умирающего мира. Здесь умирает всё, в том числе и вы. Это история где рано или поздно будет поставлена трагическая точка.

За регулярными вылазками в город в поисках медикаментов, продуктов и необходимых для выживания вещей (да-да, даже медицинскому пинцету найдется здесь дело) вы краем глаза замечаете, что и город меняется. Происходит отключение от глобальной системы энергоснабжения, постепенно прекращает свою работу трубопровод, подававший в населенные пункты воду. Еда в холодильниках портиться, и вы уже вряд ли сможете порадоваться хорошо прожаренной отбивной. Города подвергаются армейской зачистке, не сулящей вам ничего хорошего, да и ходячих с каждым днем становится всё больше.

Если совместить естественное умирание города с набегами других выживших, то картинка порой становится и вовсе унылой. Вместо богатства, ожидающего мародера посетившего брошенное место, вам часто приходиться довольствоваться каким-то мелочами. Нож для масла в качестве оружия, женская блузка вместо свитера, мусорный пакет или школьный ранец вместо хорошей сумки. собранный вручную топор, что развалится после нескольких ударов. Аутентичность на этом не заканчивается - забудете выключить газ на кухне (пока он еще остался в баллонах) и ваш дом превратиться в пепелище.

С тех пор как появился мультиплеер игра ещё больше расцвела. Помимо PVP серверов существуют PVE сервера и даже «ролевые». Попав туда, вы придерживаетесь канвы повествования. Вы больше не Ваня или Джон зашедшие покрошить других игроков. Теперь вы вполне реальный персонаж, переговаривающийся с другими выжившими по радио, помогающий другим выжить. Отыгрыш сбивает людей в группы, чтобы противостоять ходячим вместе. Богатство игровых ситуаций описать трудно. Ровно как и богатство способов умереть.

Разбил окно, полез в закрытый дом, разодрался в кровь влезая в него, впоследствии умер от заражения. Отравился плохой едой, отлеживался в каком-то доме, оказался в осаде - умер, будучи съеденным, заживо. Попал в засаду, был ранен, убежал, нашел какой-то дом полный алкоголя. Долго пил и радовался жизни. Выздоровел. Вышел наружу и столкнулся с ордой. Долго удирал от нее, забаррикадировался в каком-то отеле, затем спрыгнул с крыши второго этажа, сломал бедро, отполз в местный туалет и там умер. Всё это проза PZ дня. А ведь есть романы, поэзия. Всё это у вас будет, и каждый ваш опыт от игровой сессии будет разным.

Хотите быть фермером и уйти от этого кошмара – это возможно. Хотите быть скавенджером и войти в историю маленького мира как лучший сборщик всякой всячины – не воспрещается. Хотите стать торгашом, по прозвищу Консерва-Боб, собрав всевозможные консервы и затем устроить магазин – да пожалуйста.  Хотите прослыть самым жестоким «убийцей на западе» доступно и это. Вы можете быть кем угодно, и прожить свой конец как угодно. Какой путь вы бы не выбрали - он будет оригинальным. Вас может погубить что угодно. К примеру, осколки стекла, застрявшие в руке, когда вы разбили стекло очередного дома. Спасти вас, впрочем, тоже может что угодно. Меня спасли грибы и дождевые черви. Серьезно. Их тоже можно есть. Правда от такой пищи наступает депрессия.

Определенно – маленькая жемчужина, которая со временем станет настоящим жемчужным ожерельем или колье. Не поддержать такую игру будет неверным решением. Сейчас она, до сих пор в EA, до сих пор развивается, до сих пор дарит каждой своей сессией что-то новое.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

No real easy multiplayer options yet, unless you join neglected servers.  They exist, and it is possible to host a server, but awkward for a computer novice.  BUT, a very fun adventure that captures the essence of isolation, desperation, and determination inherent in a survival experience.  The fact that there are zombies just gives a backdrop.  A lot of little details that leave you with a robust and lovingly-crafted world to explore.  This game has medications such as beta-blockers, sleeping aids, painkillers, and even vitamins.  Name another game with that.

Also, there seems to be a lot of active development and mod content from the community.  I'm not certain how much longer the challenge of existing will keep me occupied in a single player experience, but I can certainly envision this game's development will bring me back periodically to enjoy the new content.

Would buy again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This project has been in the works for AGES. Overall, its a fun zombie apocalypse single player survival game. It is however not without its fair share of missing features and bugs at the moment. Dont let the talk of mplay mislead you, it has been in the works forever and as someone who has been with the game since early alpha, i dont see that happening anytime soon. It is fun and imo well worth the 15$ price. Its no State of Decay and comparing the two is like comparing strawberrys and candy bars. Both are yummy, but there is a big difference.

###UPDATE###

Mplayer has been implemented and it is indeed a fun romp. A bit buggy at the moment, but with time all the quirks will be worked out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Project Zomboid is hands down my favourite sandbox survival simulator, primarily because you can tell the devs are just hardcore genre fans. The atmosphere of doom looming really brings out a horror game. It's like the game is telling you in advance: you will fail.
Atmosphere is great.
Updates are actively coming, so the game is not stagnant.
Community is healthy and engaged, the devs are actively engaged with their players.

The game itself really fits the old control style I personally like. Some would call it dated for not using 50 shortcut keys for everything, but I happen to like the mouse driven context menu interface.

Music is superb. Setting is superb, and generic enough to craft any roleplay scenario the admin desires.
What's best - the multiplayer option to run a dedicated server.

Great job, Indie Stone!

I'll be honest, I don't normally get into these kinds of games, but this game gripped me due to the sheer reality of it all, and I would say it is a must have for anyone who enjoys zombie-type games. The really cool thing about it is, it's not even finished yet, which means there is more to come in it, and it's already great! I would highly recommend Project Zombid.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My experience so far with this game has been amazing.

Starting out I really didn't know what I was doing. Knowing I could loot stuff I just crammed it into my endless pockets.
Only to realize there is most certainly a weight system and I'm now bogged down.
So I drop everything but food and drink.
Travelling outside the house I see my first zombie and I immediately walk the other way.
Find a house that just happens to be locked up.... so of course I crack open the window.
Suddenly I see my zombie friend from before shambling towards me.
So I get inside and close the window.
Start searching the house for stuff only to find a zombie in the upstairs bedroom.... Must have been the homeowner.
Good morale booster right?
So I removed them only to hear some glass shatter.
My friend is definitely coming for me now..... So I grab all the clothes I can and make a rope to climb down.
Place it in the window..... and instead of using the rope I climbed out the window.
Two story fall isn't the greatest for my character, his legs were shattered.
My zombie friend also happened to bring plenty of friends with him that I didn't know about.

Best first death ever.

You can play this game numerous amounts of times and no matter how much you learn and get better you will still lose. Every. Damn. Time.
But that's what makes it great. Knowing that I have to beat all of these different factors to even survive for a while makes me want to get better. All of the new features they add constantly just upgrade the amount of fun I'm having.

I would definitely recommend this to anyone that likes Zombie Survival or just Survival by itself.

Definately a favorite. 5/5, many stars, cant wait for more content. BUY IT

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alt-tabbed to look up some crafting instructions. Logged back in to find I'd starved to death. My cabbage farm shall live on for all eternity. 10/10.

In all seriousness, this is a really solid game. Don't let the retro graphics or early access fool you - yes, it has it's bugs, it's flaws and a lot of content still to come, but you can easily pour hours into this game, especially in coop. The attention to detail around the perk system, base-building, sound travelling, etc. is a sign this developer knows what they're doing and it's a really nice example of a zombie-survival game taking a slightly different tack from the rest of the pack.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yup I would recommend this right away.

It's not an easy game I'll say that now.
Building your character is a challenge, you can build your character to be weak as heck but able to learn everything quicker and get a jump start on some skills;  you do end up easily killable but if you survive long enough you can end up being the most powerful aspect of your team later on.

Downside is the stuff that can get you swarmed by zombies: Helicopters and Gunshots {Helicopters fly over your current location and end up getting you swarmed like it did my Fiancé and I}

Other downside for those who like emersion, they don't have all the basic unique hair colors such as gingers or pitch black hair, and the mod doesn't seam to work for MP.

Aside from all of that it's a great game and I do enjoy it, but it's better played with others than alone; unless you like being completely destroyed without any backup.
voteText: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't remember exactly when I first bought this game (long before it arrived on Steam), but it was at least 7 years ago.

Very little seems to have changed since then. They spent two years working on a whole new game engine and map tools, which perhaps was of long term benefit, but what have they done in the other 5 years? Added some crafting and farming (fair enough, good), multiplayer (could have waited in favour of other stuff), redid interfaces, stats and other minor stuff.

If you buy the game, you will get some enjoyment out of it for a while. You'll enjoy exploring the town, breaking in to various buildings and searching for useful stuff to help you survive, dodging or fighting off zombies along the way. You'll enjoy trying to build your zombie proof home.

And then you'll get bored of it. The developers might keep you interested in how the development is going with their weekly essays on how awesome the game is going to be once they add the extra features that they've been working on for the last X years, but even that will wear thin sooner or later.

If you're bored and want a distraction for a little while, then perhaps buy this and play it until you get bored again. But don't buy it based on promised content or improvements 'cos it'll be years away, if it arrives at all.

Edit: For those questioning my time frame. I moved house about 5 years ago, and I played Zomboid at least a year or two before that, back when it was using Java (before the change of game code/engine, as stated above). Long before Steam EA (as stated above), so don't bother quoting that at me.

Plenty of other games just as complex have been fully developed on EA and released in that time, so the argument development takes time"
date: yes it does. But for someone who has been following this game on and off for so long
recommended: this is just getting silly.\n\nGive it a couple more years
hoursPlayed: we'll see if you're still as zealous then."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Project Zomboid Video Review!
Project Zomboid-An isometric sandbox zombie survival game by The Indie Stone. In my humble opinion, one of the best survival games to date especially considering that there are a lot of zombie/survival games. I haven’t reviewed an early access title before, but, I wanted to do my part, however small, to help out The Indie Stone and make people aware of this amazing game, this studio has done amazing work despite all their troubles and I think that that’s really admirable, I won’t go into detail but, if you’re curious I would suggest researching on the net to find out more.  *PC*This game is only on PC. The options for the game are befitting of a PC, the game itself isn’t a major powerhouse so much older systems should have no problem running the game, and currently you can play with a controller (with split-screen co-op!) A very good PC game.  *PLOT*There is no story to speak of at the time of this review, there are however, plans to bring a story mode to the finished game, sandbox is all you’ll find. You do however have a lot of options for your sandbox game, going so far as to decided how long the apocalypse has been going on for (with gameplay changes, more on that later),the game simply starts by putting you inside a house with the crazy world outside.  *STYLE*This game is isometric (top-down view) with art style that reminds me of Commands 2 Men of Courage, it’s got great detail and a very fitting look, I like this type of realistic style because, the proportions of the character to the world makes sense and, the world itself is very realistic with buildings and houses that look more modern. I do wish there were more style differences with clothes, weapons and zombies (especially as time goes on) but, what’s here is still pretty good (plus the game is mod-able) and there is always more being added. The music in this game can be very moody and fitting, this is my own personal taste but, I personally dislike the music with the parts of the middle eastern music (seems like a lot of zombie games have it strangely enough), it’s not that I dislike the genre in general, but, the game has this music that makes it feel very somber, sometimes peaceful, sometimes depressing, and it really gets me into the game, however, when that music starts in (and the women makes the ‘chanting’ noise) I get completely ripped out of it, it’s very jarring in my opinion, I think the game would be better with a focus on atmospheric music similar to that of Fallout or Wasteland 2 even, again it’s a personal preference of mine but, the style and feel of this game just doesn’t seem fitting with that type of music. Still a great style overall, I really enjoy isometric games as I feel you can get a lot more out of it visually and that especially works well with Project Zomboid.  *GAMEPLAY* Project Zomboid is perhaps one of the most realisticgames I have ever played and I don’t use that term often in association with video games. The game rewards you for very logical thinking, more so than in most video games (not to say video games need logic to be fun, but, referring to Payday 2, logically you shouldn’t be able to answer pagers period, much less four) as such this game is all about survival. Besides taking care of the basics, you’ll need to keep your character healthy and sane, really the only thing missing is your characters don’t have to shower, or, go to the bathroom, everything else is pretty much there, the first aid system is pretty involved too, I climbed through a broken window, had to take out glass shards with tweezers, disinfect the cuts, and when the bandages got too bloody, had to replace them and clean the old ones. The other part of what adds to the realism is the length of time, you have great control over your settings of the world and can make it match up with the real world if you so wish, either way, in-game healing isn’t instant, if you break a bone you’re looking at a few weeks in-game before its healed, suffering from the negative affect all the while. Farming also takes months to yield any results, and that’s assuming your planets don’t get trampled by zombies or die of disease and you’re watering them regularly. As time progresses eventually, the running water and power that are available in the houses (or not depending on your options) will turn off, you’ll need to plan ahead for these and if you don’t it’ll be a slow painful death.  *COMBAT*Combat is pretty simple, you have your choice of melee weapons, guns and throwing weapons (like the classic Molotov-cocktail), you ready your weapon, point in a direction and swing/shoot. The longer you ready your weapon, the better the accuracy, and when zombies get close you can shove them away (some may even fall over) and either make a run for it or bash their brains in. Goes without saying that loud noises attracts more zombies and, fire spreads so be careful. You can also sneak past zombies. Combat does take its toll on your character, it’s enjoyable if simple, hopefully more weapons and toys are added to make going out with a bang more of a literal option.  *VERDICT*If you enjoy survival games or zombie games, you’ll love this game, this is the most realistic game I’ve played. Honestly, even if you don’t this is the type of game that is so good it might get you into a genre you’ve never tried before. Its co-op and local split screen, so if you’ve got a passive interest I highly encourage you to check it out, maybe get a friend to play with you, it can and is a lot of fun. And it’s priced at $14.99 USD and I see it on sale often, it’s well worth the asking price. Thank you The Indie Stone for an amazing game!  TL/DRA zombie survival game from The Indie Stone, they’ve hit some rough patches, but, have still created one of the best survival games to date which is still only in early access. There is a ton of stuff planned for the future, but, what is here is a great game, it’s rewarding in all the right ways, makes you feel awesome for being smart and playing like a real survivalist. Its co-op and local split-screen, and the regular price is $14.99 USD which is a steal for this amazing game. If you’ve ever had any interest I highly encourage you to take a hard look and really consider grabbing this game, it simply deserves to be played and I get excited for the day it finally sees a full release.  Thanks for the amazing experience  The Indie Stone!

–Two Thumbs Up from Royial
Video Reviews @: The-RoyialNetwork

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros:
Sandbox zombie apocalypse survival
Loot!
Excellent mods

Cons:
Gets boring late game
Slow, and I mean sloooow, development
No NPCs (it gets lonely real quick)

I would have liked to recommend this game, but won't. It's been in EA for very long but one of what should've been a very important and prioritised feature is still not implemented. When viewed in perspective of the amount of time in development, it is rather difficult to justify.

Doubtlessly, it is fun in it's depressing, terrifying and lonely way, as evidenced by the number of hours I've sunk into it. But ultimately, what should've been finished, or at least, out of EA by now, still isn't.

Wait for the game to finish before buying. Unless you just want to hoard loot.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

i love this game i do think you should watch some youtube videos to see if its your type of game. at first glance the graphics might turn you off, but stick with it the game and crafting and survival aspect is more then in depth enough that you dont even notice. even without mods like hydrocraft there are so many building and crafting options to survive. i also like the costum sandbox options you can even pick the zombie build ( how fast they move, how strong, even how zombification is transmitted or not transmitted, also how long you have before you turn)
i love zombie games i have so many and this one is a new fav this is a true zombie SURVIVAL game, by that i mean your worst enemy in this game isnt always the zombies. its the rain making you wet and get sick, or its not having food orwater when the water and power go off. or its that cut you got breaking into a house to loot. there are many many moodlet bubbles in this gaem that add a sense of realism to the game.
the maps are pre set meaning they are Not random, usually i dont like this as you get to used to the map and the game replayability is lessened but this map is so huge it would take me hours in real time to make it across this map even longer if you count having to stop to eat and drink and rest so the fixed map you will have trouble getting bored of. and if you do there are several additional maps in the workshop that just add small towns right to the existing map expanding on it. there is so much to offer with this game that from what i see anyways doesnt have alot of glitches that i have experienced. there are so many ways to play this game. stay in town and be a looter or move out to the more wooded areas and start a farm. saying that id like to say im super impressed with the farming system that offers things like different water requirments for different plants, fertilizer even making mildew or other plant cures to care for your farm.
the stat and lvling system is a hard grind unless you find books to read to give you xp multipliers but i love the hunting for books or magazines that have new recipies i havent found yet. this game is a good option for those who love their zombie games but want a more realistic apocalyse then a shoot 'em up zombie game like left for dead (also awesome fyi)
the building reminds me of the sims sort of the looting hmm like dead island or dying light in terms of lots of junk items or less used items but there is so much content this is really a game worth some attention even if the first glance reminded me of a game id played in the 80s or early 90s this game definatly did more then impress me as this is my first review i felt compelled to make. for an early access game this game is heading down the right path to be a very successful game. the developers appear to be attentive and care about feed back and concerns from the players. if your thinking about it try the demo you may want to play the demo a few times as you play as a bitten character so you have 2-3 in game days to play but it will give you a short idea of the rough game play though the demo doesnt really give the game justice it really helped me make my choice to buy this game. the online multiplayer function is also makes this game even better, i enjoy playing this game with others the servers make the game even more realistic. as you can go it alone or find a group or partner to survive and thrive with. on the other side on a pvp server you can do the same or just be a bandit or form a gang and kill other survivors to get their gear the choice is yours in Project Zomboid

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI was agoraphobic, so I decided that staying inside the house was my best option for survival. There was plenty of food, clothes, things to barricade the windows with, etc.. but good things don't last forever. All it took was one zombie to call the others. I ran upstairs as I heard the windows shattering behind me. I panicked and ran into the bathroom where I knew there was a window, but they found me. I could see them surrounding my house in herds. I didn't have much of a choice when they started to beat down the bathroom door, so I opened the window and jumped into the crowd. With a broken leg and the rain drenching my clothes, I limped away...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I had heard a lot about this game on Reddit, and it eventuallly sparked enough of my interest to make this the very first early-access/alpha/beta game I have purchased on steam. I have stayed up until 6am playing this.

If you like isometric, survival/crafting, zombie, adventure, rpg games, then you will absolutely love Project Zomboid!

For an isometric game, the aesthetics are fantastic! The detail put into the environment is great, and the building/wall camera vision style will switch automatically, allowing you to always see your character (think Sims style) - unless, of course, you are being swarmed by zombies. There is also a great field of vision mechanic where you can only see in a cone radius in front of your character - so you can turn around to see a zombie standing right next to you (this game has prompted many screams from me lol). The music is perfect for the inensity of the game, of every single moment where it can be your last.

The controls can take a little bit of getting used to, especially considering that you have multiple menus to deal with (ex: inventory, character stats). You have the option of keeping the menus locked open, making looting much faster if you can handle the space each menu takes up on the screen.

There is a lot you can do in PZ, and it is highly recommended that you keep the unofficial map handy for quick reference. The game allows you to choose your profession, which will grant skills like higher resistance to zombie bites and scratches. You can also balance perks and negative skills, making the game more interesting. The custom mode provides a way to test out the game, allowing you to select the frequency of encountering zombies, their overall stats, how long until the electricity and water supply run out (yes, this is a critical element of the game), etc. If you want to get a good feel of the game, I recommend you start of here, just so you can better understand what you need to do without the pressure of dying at a moment's notice.

The learning curve and difficulty of this game is moderate, however, I would consider survival mode (how the game is meant to be played) to be fairly hard.

You will start off at in a random house, with only the clothes on your back. From here, you can loot supplies, hopefully finding some sort of bag item - which you can wear on your back, increasing your carrying capacity. Securing food and water is essential. Any container objects like bowls or bottles can be used to hold water from the sink, and this is critical to remember because the water supply will eventually run out. Perishable food will rot when not refrigerated.

You increase in proficiencies as you do certain things - for example, whever you sneak around zombies you will gain points in nimblness, sneaking, etc. When you attain enough xp points, you will be able to master" the first level of a "completed" skill. So
date: if I have cooked enough meals to fill my first block on the skill menu (level 1)
recommended: and have a level up point
hoursPlayed: I can select the skill
voteText: mastering it and improving the quality of things that I cook. You will not be able to fill higher level skill blocks until you first master the lowest tier - this prevents you from just cooking for the entire game since you have to be mastering each level as you progress. Reading specialty books also provides a bonus multiplier to the respective skill
helpfulPercent: and there are different books for both skills
votesHelpful: and their respective levels (ex: carpentry for begineers vs. advanced carpentry).\n\nWhile you play
votesTotal: you will have to balance your needs
votesFunny: eating
commentsCount: sleeping
column16: and staying hydrated. You can also get bored if you are inactive
column17: and becoming unhappy is also a possibility (leads to depression). There are items you can take to help with these needs (like beta pills
column18: antidepressants
column19: reading newspapers
column20: etc)
column21: and you can also take sleeping pills to allow you to go to bed (you cannot keep sleeping unless your character is actually tired) - this is very useful for trying to settle sleeping patterns into a rhythm where you are sleeping during night time and awake in time to maximize the daylight visibility.\n\nThe crafting is not too complex
column22: you will need to find an axe and chop down trees for logs
column23: then convert them into wood. Crafting a rain collector is a priority - with successfully finding an area to plant/farm as a close second.\n\nI have played this game a lot
column24: and there was one time when I had spent 3 hours securing a base and building nice walls around it. I even had set up a farm and rain barrel
column25: with pretty decent skills leveled up already. While looting a nearby house
column26: I opened a window
column27: but the alarm went off. Being overconfident in my abilities
column28: I went in anyway
column29: thinking I would be able to loot and leave before the house was stormed by zombies. While looting the upstairs rooms
column30: I heard the door break open. I quickly run down and spot zombies rushing in through the front door. I try the back door
column31: but zombies are piling in from a broken window next to the fridge. Panicking
column32: I run upstairs
column33: loot a shirt
column34: tear it into sheet rope
column35: and fashion a climbable rope on the second-level window. I slide down
column36: but zombies are surrounding the house
column37: and I have no way out. I hop over a broken window on the first floor and attempt to juke through the zombie horde. I take a scratch
column38: and immediately see that I am about to die. I try to drop my bag
column39: but it is too late. I have joined the dead.\n\nI stare at the screen for a good 2 minutes
column41:
then load up a new game.

I love this game.

If you load a save where you have died
column42: everything you have done will remain intact
column43: so securing and transforming a safehouse will not be wasted. You can even find your corpse walking around if you are lucky.\n\nThe mod support is not as extensive as say
column46: there is a lot of potential for great user-made content. The developers
column49: releasing builds at good intervals. Be warned
column51: not to invest to much in your saves
column52: as you may not be able to transfer over your saves to newer builds when they are released.\n\nIf you are interested at all
column53: give this game a try. For an early-access game
column54: it is quite impressive and very well-done.\n\nHighly recommend!"

You increase in proficiencies as you do certain things - for example, whever you sneak around zombies you will gain points in nimblness, sneaking, etc. When you attain enough xp points, you will be able to master" the first level of a "completed" skill. So
