reviewText:
Early Access Review

These are the end-times
There was no hope of survival
This is how you died"

Every time I start up the game and see those words I get chills.  Project Zomboid is an isometric view survival zombie game. It involves managing hunger/thirst
hoursPlayed: zombies
voteText:
and figuring out how to live once the power and water shuts off.  You can tell by my hours spent in game I LOVE it!

Pros

A very unique game.  I have never played anything like it. Every time I play this game I want to watch The Walking Dead. Every time I watch The Walking Dead I want to play this game.  It is a custom built game engine that is THE zombie survival game I always wanted.

Updates are meaningful and consistent.  Every time an update comes out I know I am in for a treat.  You can test the update before it is part of the official steam release
helpfulPercent:
but I only did that once. When they release it the update is very stable with only very minor bugs.

There is a sense of desperation. As you character gets panicked and tired and you are far from your safe house the tension goes up.  When you finally use that gun you know you will be overwhelmed by a horde because of the noise.  Scavenging has never been so fun.

Multiplayer adds a great way to play with friends or join a server for  more competitive play.

Modding is supported. Players are starting to make really cool custom maps and interesting mods.

It is just fun.

Cons

Once you clear out an area
votesHelpful: establish you house
votesTotal: create a few rain barrels
votesFunny: and start farming
commentsCount: the game looses lots of tension. Zombies don't spawn after you kill so many. The engine redistributes zombies by in game events that are limited to gun fire and helicopter noises
column16:
but in practice they don't bring that many after you truly cleared your area and the surrounding area.  In one game I no longer feel I am in threat of dying.

The early history of the game has a pretty bad black eye involving loosing all their work because they didn't back it up and their laptops were stolen.  TotalBiscuit still referenced it recently when he talked about it in his breakdown of the daily summer sales.

Finale Thoughts

Build 27 (the current stable build as I write this) advances the game to the point I can finally wholeheartedly recommend it.  Even if they never do another update
column17: the game is fun enough and unique enough to establish itself as a worthy game at full price.\n\nThere is a challenge mode
column18: multiplayer
column19: and mods. Even if you get to the point of feeling safe (like I do now)
column20: I can always start new or jump on my online server with friends
column21: join a public server
column22: or try the challenge mode.   I am going to see how long my current guy can last. So far 700+ zombies killed and over 2 months alive! woot!!\n\nBUT...it is not going to stop updating anytime soon. The most anticipated update is NPCs. They used to be in the game
column23: but they rebuilt under the hood stuff so they can introduce them with a sadistic AI. It will open up a higher degree of tension and give modders great tools to work with.\n\nThe UI is slated to be updated
column24: crafting and skills keep getting tweaked (as they should be)
column25: and minor bugs are getting ironed out. The map is expanding
column26: items and recipes are increasing
column27:
and new features are still being implemented.

I believe they are even working on a system to better redistribute zombies or keep them spawning. I hope so anyway.  I thought I read that they intend to add more zombie spawning options-multiplayer servers particularly need that option as they cuurently depend on the admin manually spawning zombies.

As of now admins can also do a soft reset that respawns zombies and loot
column28: turns back on power and water while restarting the clock to their shutdown
column29:
but the soft reset keeps player crafted buildings intact.

It will be better if automated zombie spawning is implemented or zombie spawning scripts can be utilized.

The company has more then atoned for their early days and are a shining example of being persistent and overcoming very real mistakes and making a better product for it.  Don't be fooled by old reviews or info.

This is the golden age to get the game. Full price is still cheap. The current full price is worth it. The Indie Stone has enough of a track record and community involvement to feel confident this great game will only get better. Don't pass this one up!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off I want to say that I don't really play the single player of this game, so the review is based entirely on multiplay.

I personally love playing this game with friends... it's the only multiplayer zombie survival game I've come across that I've enjoyed.  It's incredibly simple, yet incredibly complicated at the same time.  Don't expect to just jump in the game and do well... the wiki is an incredibly valued resource that you will need to read over at least once.  I'll also mention that this is an early access game, but doesn't play like one.  Far too often we see games launch as early access which are barely playable... project zomboid however is wonderful.  Take note devs... this is how you early access.

What really caused me to love this game was that they actually managed to get zombies right.  Far too often do zombie games have overpowered, super monsters.  Zombies are slow, stupid, and easy to kill... their danger comes in their numbers... this is something almost every piece in zombie related media screws up.  Project zomboid nails it though.  Suburbs have fewer zombies than cities, and a city has the number you would expect (note: it's a lot).

The game very accurately lets you feel what it would be like to be an ordinary person thrust deep into a zombie apocalypse... think you'd be able to survive? Think again.  I strongly recommend this game to people (at least if you have friends to play with... I've heard a lot of complaints about single player not being nearly as entertaining).  The greatest thing the creators of this game did was give you the option to modify the world.  You can alter how long it takes for the electricity and water to turn off, how sparse loot is, how many zombies there are, experience multipliers, whether or not loot respawns, how quick zombies are... all of it.  You can really try out all sorts of scenarios.  And how easily the game is modded... this allows a lot of user generated content to enhance the experience.

Cons of the game:

- Combat takes a little bit to get used to and can be frustrating to newcomers.  It's a shame, but practice and I guarantee you'll get over it.
- The zombie virus infection rate can't be altered.  Currently it's 96% infection rate on a bite, and 25% on a scratch.  I'd love to see these numbers be customizable to the server (personally I'd love 100% bite and 0% scratch)... but I think them adding this feature would improve the game drastically
- There is no in game map.  You would think if you lived in a city you would know your way around it... unfortunately you have to figure this out for yourself.  There is a map online, but I think either having a map option or adding a map as a rare loot would be a wonderful addition.
- Multiplay can be tough to set up at first... especially if you need to port forward.  I would love to see them implement some form of steam assisted multiplayer setup including Invite to Game" option.
- [EDIT: THIS HAS BEEN FIXED] Having items with durability or that are equipped that stack in your inventory can cause issues.  When you want to drop one but can't specify which one you can spend a bit of time fumbling.  Nothing is worse when you're running from zombies
date: but carrying too much weight so you decide you want to drop your second baseball bat
recommended: only to find that you dropped the one you had equipped and now you have no weapon equipped to defend yourself.  And I can't tell you how many times I've chosen to rip a spare shirt into bandages only for my character to disrobe and rip the one he's wearing instead.\n\nThe cons seem many and the pros seem few
hoursPlayed: but I assure you they aren't... that's just my inability to articulate properly.  The game is really enjoyable and I recommend it to everyone.  The pricetag is a little high in my opinion
voteText: but still a wonderful game to pick up."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The best zombie game I've ever played, whether you're playing coop or solo. As you go on it gets progressivly harder and adds different challenges. At the beginning you have to find food, shelter, weapons, and avoid zombies. Eventually you'll have to worry about defending a fortress, growing your own food because you've looted all of it (unless you have loot respawn on) and getting the most use out of your tools, which will eventually break. Another great thing is that there is a lot of customization in the sandbox mode; you can have a lot of zombies or even no zombies, you can change how long into the apocolypes you are (o-12 months in), you can change how fast nature takes over, how fast crops grow, the spawn rate of zombies and loot, the rarity of loot, and even the lore of the zombies; are they fast or slow? how well can they navigate? (can they use doors or not?) how long does it take to get infected? how easy is it to get infected? how good is their memory? how good is their hearing, sight, and smell? the list goes on. It's also quite easy to set up a server, even if you don't want to take the time to port forward (meaning you use a program such as Hamachi). All the files that are need to run the server are already in the directory. Servers are also expected to be brought over to Steam in the near future.

If you're the kind of person that doesn't trust Early Access games, don't worry about this. This game is, in my opinion, good enought to be a full game. It's also not that expensive; $17 CAN full price. I'd pay up to $30 or more for this. Also the game is still in development so their adding more stuff and at a fast rate too. At the time of writing this review, they are working on adding syncronized TVs that update you on the situation of the world and a massive new city. You can stay updated on what their doing on the mondoid website, which is constantly updated.

Should you buy this? ♥♥♥♥ yes!
Should you tell your friends to buy this? ♥♥♥♥ yes!
Should you tell your grandma to buy this? Holy ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥ yes!                                                          ... unless she's dead.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alahaha-mazing game. At its early stage, it's quite a lot of fun. Future plans involve multiplayer and there's already local co-op (but it's quite buggy). The team's main focus is on the core system and mechanics right now. I HIGHLY encourage anyone interested in the game to check out its website for more information about its future plans (more specifically, their metagame and NPCS). There are some amazing features surrounding the game that are quite close to being implemented.
If you have the money and want the game, just buy it. It's worth it and the developers need as much as they can get.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off id like to state this game is of a top down veiw. You are able to zoom in and out and the whole objective is to surviveby any means. This game (being a favorite of mine.) offers only one set ending. Your death. By what means? Who knows. Maybe your house burnt down or a zombie miss took you for a happy meal. What ever the case this is a horror suvival game. If you have a weak heart i'd suggest not playing this. Just out of caustion for your condition and the high stress of clearing out a horde infested house.
This game has a well versed medical system and the ever present way to end the game with bleach in every house. Personaly, If you like horror, survival and fortifing in a game while managing your ever depleting beef jerky supplie, well what can I say. Go to the supper market after you get this game. :P

Early Access Review

Let me start off this review by saying this; These game devs, are not like all the others. They care about their game, AND their community. They listen to what you have to say, and take it into great consideration. THAT BEING SAID; their update progress is slow. When they do update the game however, hardly anything is broken.

The game as it stands, is very very enjoyable; with a great community. Gameplay can change at a moments notice, as you are sorting through your bag, a zombie could take a bite out of your neck, yikes! Project Zomboid makes you feel afraid. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI've followed the progress of this game for roughly two years now and I must say I LOVE this game. When I was a kid I literally dreamed about having a game like this and now I do. Yes, there have been some set backs in it's progress along the way but even in Early Access this game is AMAZING and the developers are still adding features. HUGE map, great crafting system, hundreds of buildings to fortify and make your own as well as plenty Zed to kill and burn. This game isn't just hands down my favorite indie game, it's one of my favorite games of all time. I recommend this game to anyone who loves base-building, city-looting, zombie-killing fun. 11/10 Would accidently burn down the school again

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ever wonder how far you could make it in a zombie apocalypse?

Well this is Project Zomboid, and this is the story of how you died.

Project Zomboid is nothing short of a pure survival game.

While still in early access, at the time of this review at least, one could be forgiven and even possibly agreed with to say that PZ is a finished game. While the statement is untrue, the premise behind it is. Right now, at the current momment, the game has more than enough content to fullfill your needs. That's right, the developers could literally  say the game was done and I would still buy it at the final price. The game has a hardcore survival mode, sandbox mode, and a last stand mode I am yet to try. More are on the way.

While the game does not have a lot of weapons (at least, not a lot of firearms) in the current state, every weapon type has it's standard use that would lead the player to not need much variation anyways. That doesn't mean more variation isn't coming though, because it is.

If you liked Minecraft, State of Decay, or any other freedom-weighted survival game, PZ is a must have for your library.

Despite the surprisingly great polish, it is apparently nowhere near finished. The devs are hard workers that know what's going on and update with new, big things over time. A lot of the reason behind the slow progress is that they have a good habit of 'streamlining' their new additions before they put them out, instead of just putting out the base feature only to slowly update it and fix major bugs that could have been caught early on, unlike some other games (I'm looking at you, Dead Linger). That habit also supports the thought that the game could be a finished product in it's current state, as basically everything the game has set in currently all functions.

And the multiplayer in the game is spectacular. Situations like those portrayed on TV and in stories just naturally happen in the game. You can set up a functioning, self-supporting community with a large group of people and deal with players, zombies, injuries, social issues and the other obvious things just as you would in something like the Walking Dead, not requiring roleplay or structured events for it to work. And the fact that you can do anything you want to set up your home ranging from camping under the stars to living on a rooftop is an obvious plus for this as well.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is fun, but it can and most likely will get really repetitive after a few hours. My biggest issue with this game is how slow it takes you to get from point A to point B. I mean god if you want to go to that mall or other town you'll actually have to spend a good hour or two maybe more irl just to get there. This game is in dire need of transportation, like cars or bikes. Seriously, I think this is the only zombie game I played that has zero broken down cars or working cars in it. If you are going to make a huge map like this, it needs a way to get around faster.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game takes the Zombie Survival formula and takes it so many steps further, in the best of ways. I recommend this to anyone who remembers the good ol' days before the Walking Dead made everyone a zombie fan. It's about as realistic as it gets to an actual zombie apocalypse, starting you off well after the infected have largely inherited the Earth. You have tons of options, and can even customize the type of zombies that would populate your world. Even while still in Early Access its a incredible game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a must-have for anyone who likes zombie survival games. To be simple, the pros and cons are below.

Good:
Very realistic
choice between multiplayer and single player
choice of how challenging you want it to be
nice combat system
great survival stats (hunger, thirst, etc.)
good crafting system
great character customization

Bad:
Complicated at times
stressful at times
sometimes needs to much for crafting/repairing things.

Thats everything i can come up with thats good or bad about that games. Did you notice that the good things double the bad things? Buy this game. its good.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the best zombie games I have played.  Despite some short comings (which they are still working on) this game is just fanstastic!

Pros
Realism without going over the top like some zombie games.
Combat is really enjoyable once you get the hang of it.
Why more fun with friends and can PVP.
Can play sandox and customize from rather easy zombies to true zombies" as they call it.
Can do cool stuff like use a rope (or make one from sheet) to climb out a window if the house gets flooded with zombies.
One of the best inventory system ever. (IMO) MIght take a bit getting used to but just make sense in terms of reaslism.

Cons
Becoming sick from zombie bite or sratch can be OP at times (like after 25 days and like 700 zombie kills one just scratches me and its game over.)  but as I pointed out you can changed that in sandbox if you dont like it.
Missing stuff like cars (imo)
Lack of other things to do such as more crafting like modding weapons more then just nailed bat and sawed off.
Lack of firearm types (only pistol
recommended: and varrmint rifle at the moment) I would like to see a couple types of each and even assault rifles SMGs
hoursPlayed: sniper rifles
voteText:
you know.
No in game map (like I cant find a map of my local area map at every gas station or store) but you can find one online.

Most of the stuff in Cons are all stuff that very well will be fixed by full release

Project zomboid was my first ever zombie game, I purchased it before it was on steam from the devs website for $5 best $5 I ever spent.

This game started my love for survival/zombie games and is a constant go to game for me.

Dont let the simplistic look of the game put you off, it has all the trimmings: crafting, base building, array of loot and of course lots of zombie killing!

With active devs this game has great features added all the time and is definitely one to check out if you like a challenge and enjoy zombie/survivial games

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAn isometric zombie survival game with Police Quest: SWAT 2-esque graphics. Which is an awesome combination. Considering it's still in early access, there is a lot you can do if you don't mind surviving by yourself (There are no NPC survivors as of this review, but there is multiplayer.) I can't comment on the multiplayer as I haven't tried it yet, but i've been having a blast playing single player. Sandbox mode also lets you customize the zombies, allowing you to change their speed, toughness, senses, you can even change how people get infected and how long it takes.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIn a world where zombies are a cultural norm, it is easy to get bored from all the same old zombie games that pop out everywhere.. There are those games... And then there is Project Zomboid... Project Zomboid asks you one simple question, When will you die?" You must fight to survive and delay your impending doom but what sets this game apart from every other zombie game is the realistic sandbox survival tone the game gives. Although it can be frustrating in the beginning due to the steep learning curves and it's hardcore permadeath YOLO style

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is possibly the best experience you will have with a post-apocalyspe genre. This game has so many features in its early version. There are hundreds of different items and foods. Tools, weapons, and materials can be used to create entire buildings up to several stories tall. There is a simple crafting system allowing you to use improvised weapons and tools as well. Carpentry, farming and cooking all of in-depth systems and recipes to get what you want and need to survive more successfully than your predecessors. You can get trapped on the second story of a building and be trapped by a ravenous horde controlling the first floor. You can choose to risk your health and life to jump out the window and make your dashing escape with or without injury...or you can rip off the curtains and tie them into a rope stable enough to lower yourself down and out of the infested building. Scavenging a local house you can open a closet to find a zombie who then rushes you and sinks his teeth into your neck. Even if you destroy him and survive you only have mere hours, possibly days before you turn. All this and more is in this game currently but don't be fooled. This is NOT a complete and perfect game. Several in-game items have no purpose even when they look useful and several items and weapons have placeholder icons or textures. Planned and promised features are aplenty such as vehicles and NPCs. This is a small developement team and will take its time making this game even greater than it already is turning out to be, be patient and you'll get a survival experience like no other.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGreat game, very in depth and no serious gamebreaking bugs encountered so far, game also saves 99% of the time if it does crash so its unlikely that you will lose progress. Generally a very good and challenging game. Main criticism would be the lack of use for some items and general little balances need doing here and there. But that is to be expected with the game being in alpha stages of development, with splitscreen and multiplayer, planned to be added in the future, this game will be amazing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Has potential, but is a bit unforgiving with fiddly controls at the moment. There's also graphical slowdowns, but that's to be expected from an un-optimised alpha.
Currently it feels like a game that needs you to play whilst having the wiki open on another screen. It's unclear as to how cooking works for example, and systems overall rely on an awful lot of trial and error, something you don't really have a lot of time for.
Controls are also a bit awkward at the moment too, feeling unresponsive and arbitrary.
But the potential is huge. I don't think there's a zombie survival sim out there with as much depth as this one's attempting.

This is a great game, especially considering that its still in Alpha!  There are still a lot of bugs and it runs slowly and crashes at times but it is reletively playable in it's current state. As long as you are prepared to cope with these I'd deffinitely recommend buying this game in Alpha or at least trying out the demo if you're unsure.

Some areas I hope they work on or prioritise in future releases/fixes;
- Improve controls and sneaking machanic (currently sneaking doesn't seem to work well).  It would be great to be able to hide as well (maybe in some containers like bins or wardrobes).
- It would be nice to see even more weapons, features and items you can create in later releases.
- While most of the music is excellent I also hope they remove the tracks with the woman wailing over the top (it just doesn't suit the game well.  The instrumental tracks are far better!).
- It would also be nice if they allowed you to turn the permadeath mode on/off in the options.
- Improve speed of the game (sounds like this i currently in planning)
- Add the ability to fix aging weapons
- More explanation of the current ailments (although currently this can be found on their wiki - search google for 'Moodles')
- I look forward to NPC additions and I hope you can use them for fighting or carrying more items.
- Add items like carts you could build to transport lots of items long distances (i.e. if movig out to a country retreat).
- Improve the perk system.  It'd be nice to add a few positive perks without having to add negative ones (a lot of which are quite severely impacting).

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is possibly the best experience you will have with a post-apocalyspe genre. This game has so many features in its early version. There are hundreds of different items and foods. Tools, weapons, and materials can be used to create entire buildings up to several stories tall. There is a simple crafting system allowing you to use improvised weapons and tools as well. Carpentry, farming and cooking all of in-depth systems and recipes to get what you want and need to survive more successfully than your predecessors. You can get trapped on the second story of a building and be trapped by a ravenous horde controlling the first floor. You can choose to risk your health and life to jump out the window and make your dashing escape with or without injury...or you can rip off the curtains and tie them into a rope stable enough to lower yourself down and out of the infested building. Scavenging a local house you can open a closet to find a zombie who then rushes you and sinks his teeth into your neck. Even if you destroy him and survive you only have mere hours, possibly days before you turn. All this and more is in this game currently but don't be fooled. This is NOT a complete and perfect game. Several in-game items have no purpose even when they look useful and several items and weapons have placeholder icons or textures. Planned and promised features are aplenty such as vehicles and NPCs. This is a small developement team and will take its time making this game even greater than it already is turning out to be, be patient and you'll get a survival experience like no other.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Has potential, but is a bit unforgiving with fiddly controls at the moment. There's also graphical slowdowns, but that's to be expected from an un-optimised alpha.
Currently it feels like a game that needs you to play whilst having the wiki open on another screen. It's unclear as to how cooking works for example, and systems overall rely on an awful lot of trial and error, something you don't really have a lot of time for.
Controls are also a bit awkward at the moment too, feeling unresponsive and arbitrary.
But the potential is huge. I don't think there's a zombie survival sim out there with as much depth as this one's attempting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A masterful take on the overused Zombie Apocalypse setting, this sandbox RPG breathes fresh life into a familar situation.

The game is a labour of love from British studio The Indie Stone, as anyone who's followed the trials and tribulations of this game's development can tell you.

(Google it if unsure. RockPaperShotgun had good coverage of it as well, it's quite the dramatic saga)

Still in Early Access at time of posting this (8th Nov 2013) the game is already well polished and feature-laden. Don't be mistaken into thinking that just because it's still being developed that this is only half a game.

There isn't much more that can be said about PZ without you actually playing it, but as luck would have it, there is a demo of this title also available directly through Steam so stop reading this, and go play Project Zomboid.

Whether you end up buying the game is, obviously entirely up to you, but I think I know what you'll decide.

Enjoy.. I do. :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

We all come across a game which seems promising but once you purchase it, its the complete different. Sometimes we purchase games that are fun, but after hours of playing you loose your feel for the game. We sometimes purchase games that are hard to run without a beefy computer. Those are some of the most painful ways a passionate gamer experiences more than just once. If you do read the reviews and do your research on that game then you might feel comfident that the game is worth the purchase and you hope it won't get dry after the first week of owning the game. If you're reading this review, congratulations!

PROJECT ZOMBOID

This game is very unique from the millions of apocalyptic games. First of all its a simulator, There aren't a lot of great simulators for the apocalypse. Well most of them aren't still in EARLY development, Most of them are released as they are and don't update as frequently and have new content, but Project Zomboid does. New patches release adding new mechanics, bug fixes, customization, and so much more thats just one of the greatest aspects of Project Zomboid.

Once you launch Project Zomboid you're greeted with an amazing soundtrack. If you don't believe me launch it for yourself! At the main menu you're shown these catigories  Mods
hoursPlayed: Laststand " and in the background it shows a heartwarming illustration of what appears to be a man hugging his sick wife. In these catigories you can play Survival
voteText: Sandbox or Laststand.\n\nSURVIVAL. In survival you get to choose the two maps created so far
helpfulPercent: make your character and traits your character has and what their career was before the apocalypse struck.\n\nSANDBOX. In sandbox you get the choice to make the world how you'd like it to be. You can change the way zombies see
votesHelpful: hear
votesTotal: and smell. You can change how often loot spawns
votesFunny: the season you start in
commentsCount:
how long the water and electricity will shut off etc. . .

LASTSTAND. In laststand you instantly spawn in a house with a crate carrying weapons to defend yourself. You takedown the hordes until they break in and take you down. There is a timer so you can see how long you survived which makes it fun to challenge yourself or brag to your friends!

For the price Project Zomboid is right now I would call it a steal! 15 US dollars for a game as it is now plus all the updates and patches coming

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't normally review games, but Project Zomboid is an exceptional game. Even in it's early stages, the amount of things do to  in order to survive is incredible. It pay attention to things most games miss like the power or water cutting off. The Dev's are very vocal on the forums and are quick to respond to bugs etc. They are friendly and easy to approach if you have an idea or question. The multiplayer, even at this stage is incredibly fun as a group of you work together to try and salvage tins of food and make a stand in the bleak apocalypse. Get this game and get your friends to get it too.

EDIT
Since my last review this game has come along leaps and bounds. The aiming system has had an overhaul, making the shooting on the game more sensible and feeling right for the kind of game it is. The stamina system has been implemented so you can no longer run cross map without even breaking a sweat. Now you have to decided whether you have the energy to take those 10 zombies blocking your way, or try to get past them. The medical system has been implemented, meaning even climbing through a broken window could leave you injured. The variety of injuries and appropriate treatments has added an extra depth to the game, which is always welcome. Falling from heights now causes fractures, limiting movement speed until a splint is on the wound and a few days of rest have passed. (Hope you have a lot of skill books to pass the time!)

The erosion feature means that after a certain time has passed, the world will change. Roots and weeds will sprout through the highway, football fields will start to grow small trees, and the buildings you loot will become cracked and weatherworn. Combine this with an ever expanding map, new skills for survival such as Trapping, Foraging and a way to preserve certain foods, and the much anticipated NPC's (no ETA's!)

In short, this game remains one of the best I have played in a very long time, and i have spent many many more hours than my steam profile shows. Whenever the chance arises, i buy a copy of this game for my friends and they get immediately sucked into the game. Buy a copy, or buy a 4 pack, dish a few out to your friends, and try to start a colony in the apocalypse that is Project Zomboid.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game will show you an infinitely possible world in an unforgiving way that makes everything you do dangerous regardless of how long you've been alive.

TL;DR: 9/10 - Best zombie survival sim out there today.

Zomboid is the type of game that might take a little bit of getting used to if you haven't played something like pokemon. IT will get even harder to get used to if you haven't thought about survival situations in your life. The day I realized I loved Zomboid is when I decided to try and craft something, without knowing the recipe, a molotov cocktail. I drank a bottle of whiskey, and ripped up a sheet, I then tried pouring a bottle of whiskey on the sheet, it didn't work. A couple of game days later I came across a gas can, I substituted the whiskey for gas, and 'lo and behold a molotov was created. These are the kind of possibilities that will keep you coming back forever. Everything makes sense.

There are no shortage of oh ♥♥♥♥ I better drink some bleach because I'm about to turn in to a zombie" moments

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Probably one of the best survival games I've played, period. I've played it since the early days on Desura, and it's grown immensely since then. It's also one of a small number of Early Access games I'll actually endorse playing in an unfinished state.

Yeah, it's another zombie game, but it's explored routes that other zombie survival games have barely even considered. Sleep, hunger, and thirst are something you have to watch for obviously, yes, but at the same time there's also fear, pain, depression, boredom, sickness, even temperature is taken into consideration. And everything will affect your character in some way.

It has one of the most comprehensive damage systems I've ever seen. Rather than just You've taken damage! Don't let your health hit 0!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Project Zomboid is one of those few gems that is released every 5-7 years, where should I begin this review?

Let's start with the concept of the game. The whole idea of PZ is to survive as long as possible, there are no objectives,  no end goal, just survive. Now this may sound easy, but in a world full of zombies constantly out to get whatever they smell/hear/see this can become rather challenging. We all know what zombies are and do, they are dead corpses that were reanimated by some sort of virus or disease and now out to infect everything in sight. And if you're an avid zombie hunter, then this game may sound like just another game with zombies in it, it's not.

Let's get to the actual gameplay elements;

Crafting: You can literally build what ever type of base you want, now this is by far one of the coolest features, you can wall off entire city blocks if you wanted to. (that would require quite a bit of resources though, I'll get to that in a minute) You can build doors, floors, walls, bars, stairs, and light posts among other things. You can craft weapons, or repair ones you've broken, you can add modifications to said weapons too! Got a baseball bat, some nails, and a hammer? Create a spiked baseball bat that deals pretty significant damage and does it in style too.

Barricading: This should probably go in the crafting section, but whatever. Barricading is something most of us zombie hunters have wanted to do for some time now, and sure some zombie games do have it, but Project Zomboid executes it brilliantly, the resources required for barricading are pretty rare depending on how lucky you are and what type of settings you selected before you started your game. (only in Sandbox mode can you select said options) You can barricade windows and doors, which not only helps keep the creeping zeds at bay, but also makes it so they can't see you through said windows, which is really cool. (you can also put sheets up to block outsiders from looking into your safehouse)

Scavenging: This has been a part of modern zombie games for quite some time now, however this game does do one of the more realistic approches to it, food that you scavenge must be kept in a fridge or else it will spoil and make you sick if you attempt to eat it. Items that you need for crafting/barricading are pretty rare and thus valuable when found. You really need to pick and choose only the stuff you'll need at that moment when scavenging because you can only carry so much before becoming over encumbered, and don't forget you can always come back for whatever you can not bring with you at that time. There is another cool option about this, you can carry two bags with you at a time (this would require you to equip one bag in the secondary slot, and a big/normal, hiking/school bag equiped on your back) which gives you plenty of more space along with weight reductions applied from the bag(s) you have equiped at the time.

Moodles: These are moodlets that pop up every now and then to tell you what your character is feeling/thinking, think The Sims, it's just like that. These can range anywhere from being tired, to getting cold, you'll want to keep a close eye on these. Most are not that important, however they're are some that do require your attention and you'll want to be on the lookout for such as, exhaustion, starving, getting sick, getting cold, getting wet, (when it rains) bleeding, and being in pain. A couple tips. 1) You'll want to avoid going out looting/killing during a storm because you'll get wet and will have an increased chance of becoming sick which could be the death of you if you don't take things easy. (killing zombies, running) 2) Lay down every now and then, you're not superman, your character needs sleep just as much as you do. 3) Make sure to always carry bandages/bandaids on you, in case you need to break open a window or patch up a wound, these are a necessity.

Skills: This is a really fun feature in the game, you will develope skills according to how you play overtime. Do you like sneaking around avoiding the undead masses? Or do you like running in swinging hand over foot? either way will get you XP in these skills, which in time will unlock skill points that you can assign to your favorite most used abilities. Remember though, this is not carried over to multiple characters, if your character dies, all the abilities you've unlocked die with them.

Farming: This is a pretty cool feature, it requires quite a few resources that may or may not be tricky to find depending on where you are and what options you've chose before starting the game. I'm not too experienced in this aspect as of the time of this review, however I do know that it is a great food source after the power/water has went out. You can grow your own crops inside your safe zone, or where ever, it really doesn't matter as long as you have the right materials you need, you can start your own little Farmville. (without being bombarded with 53,721 requests from people you barely know. I'm looking at you, Facebook)

Distracting: You can distract the zombies with a few different methods, distracting a group of zombies could end up saving your life for another day. If you've got some gasoline handy and a few matches/lighter you could light up a near by house distracting the horde of undead while you easily sneak by and loot the otherwise damn near impossible house/building with ease. If you're playing with a friend(s) you can distract zombies while your friend goes in and loots the place dry by shouting at them, this will make your life a little bit harder though depending on how many of them there actually are, and Vice versa. Alams in houses can provide a quick distraction, if you're quick enough that is. Break a window or force it open in certain homes and you'll hear an alarm buzz for about 20-30 seconds, if you're quick enough to get out you can easily evade the on coming hordes making it easier to loot the outer area around the house you just sounded off, however this could very well be the end of your life if you get caught up in an oncoming group of zeds.

Weapons: As with most zombie games, this game is based on melee/close quarter combat, there are guns available, however they're pretty rare, most are found in the cities and or gun stores, but of course those areas are hard to get to and loot without proper means, meaning you'll be doing most of your killing with a good ol' baseball bat/crowbar/golfclub, which is by no means a bad choice. (well except maybe the golfclub, you'd be better off fighting them with a toothbrush) The baseball bat has pretty decent durability, and is great against zombies, you can kill most zeds with a couple blows from a baseball bat, same with the crowbar, the better more rarer melee weapons such as the Axe and Sledgehammer are great too, however they're mostly located in the city areas, consider yourself lucky if you find one in the suburbs. Guns are great for clearing out areas, just make sure that you have enough ammo on you, because once you pull that trigger, it's on, that's like a dinnerbell to the infected.

Be SMART: This game is heavily focused on realism, this isn't a game where you're an overpowered solider that cannot be killed, you can and probably will be killed quite a bit starting out. Only RUN when needed. Don't be a glutton and eat everything in sight, you may need that for another day. If you think it's a bad idea, then it is, and you shouldn't do it. And one last thing, STAY AWARE OF YOUR SURROUNDINGS AT ALL TIMES.

Those are the main features of the game as of 4/20/2014 (Yea I know what day it is har har har)

I'd like to add in that you will NEED to think before you act if you want to survive efficiently, this game is about your experience in the zombie apocalypse, what would you do in this situation if it actually happened? That's up to you, however, don't be careless, or else you will not survive for long.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Zombie apocalypse survival sim at it's finest.

The game is still in early acces but every addition to it has been nothing but amazing. You have to scavenge around abandoned buildings for supplies to survive off and if you decide to, build your own fort in the midst of the zombie apocalypse. Incredibly immersive with its wound and crafting system that allow you to build things like spiked baseball bats and sawn-off shotguns. Despite it not really being a horror game exactly it still manages to get a good jump out of you when you're investigating houses and some zombie decided to hide in a corner you can't see it.

The community of developers does an incredible job of rolling out updates and keeping the fanbase informed and there's even a modding communiy. Just get this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't normally review games, but Project Zomboid is an exceptional game. Even in it's early stages, the amount of things do to  in order to survive is incredible. It pay attention to things most games miss like the power or water cutting off. The Dev's are very vocal on the forums and are quick to respond to bugs etc. They are friendly and easy to approach if you have an idea or question. The multiplayer, even at this stage is incredibly fun as a group of you work together to try and salvage tins of food and make a stand in the bleak apocalypse. Get this game and get your friends to get it too.

EDIT
Since my last review this game has come along leaps and bounds. The aiming system has had an overhaul, making the shooting on the game more sensible and feeling right for the kind of game it is. The stamina system has been implemented so you can no longer run cross map without even breaking a sweat. Now you have to decided whether you have the energy to take those 10 zombies blocking your way, or try to get past them. The medical system has been implemented, meaning even climbing through a broken window could leave you injured. The variety of injuries and appropriate treatments has added an extra depth to the game, which is always welcome. Falling from heights now causes fractures, limiting movement speed until a splint is on the wound and a few days of rest have passed. (Hope you have a lot of skill books to pass the time!)

The erosion feature means that after a certain time has passed, the world will change. Roots and weeds will sprout through the highway, football fields will start to grow small trees, and the buildings you loot will become cracked and weatherworn. Combine this with an ever expanding map, new skills for survival such as Trapping, Foraging and a way to preserve certain foods, and the much anticipated NPC's (no ETA's!)

In short, this game remains one of the best I have played in a very long time, and i have spent many many more hours than my steam profile shows. Whenever the chance arises, i buy a copy of this game for my friends and they get immediately sucked into the game. Buy a copy, or buy a 4 pack, dish a few out to your friends, and try to start a colony in the apocalypse that is Project Zomboid.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Project Zomboid is one of those few gems that is released every 5-7 years, where should I begin this review?

Let's start with the concept of the game. The whole idea of PZ is to survive as long as possible, there are no objectives,  no end goal, just survive. Now this may sound easy, but in a world full of zombies constantly out to get whatever they smell/hear/see this can become rather challenging. We all know what zombies are and do, they are dead corpses that were reanimated by some sort of virus or disease and now out to infect everything in sight. And if you're an avid zombie hunter, then this game may sound like just another game with zombies in it, it's not.

Let's get to the actual gameplay elements;

Crafting: You can literally build what ever type of base you want, now this is by far one of the coolest features, you can wall off entire city blocks if you wanted to. (that would require quite a bit of resources though, I'll get to that in a minute) You can build doors, floors, walls, bars, stairs, and light posts among other things. You can craft weapons, or repair ones you've broken, you can add modifications to said weapons too! Got a baseball bat, some nails, and a hammer? Create a spiked baseball bat that deals pretty significant damage and does it in style too.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Probably one of the best survival games I've played, period. I've played it since the early days on Desura, and it's grown immensely since then. It's also one of a small number of Early Access games I'll actually endorse playing in an unfinished state.

Yeah, it's another zombie game, but it's explored routes that other zombie survival games have barely even considered. Sleep, hunger, and thirst are something you have to watch for obviously, yes, but at the same time there's also fear, pain, depression, boredom, sickness, even temperature is taken into consideration. And everything will affect your character in some way.

It has one of the most comprehensive damage systems I've ever seen. Rather than just You've taken damage! Don't let your health hit 0!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game will show you an infinitely possible world in an unforgiving way that makes everything you do dangerous regardless of how long you've been alive.

TL;DR: 9/10 - Best zombie survival sim out there today.

Zomboid is the type of game that might take a little bit of getting used to if you haven't played something like pokemon. IT will get even harder to get used to if you haven't thought about survival situations in your life. The day I realized I loved Zomboid is when I decided to try and craft something, without knowing the recipe, a molotov cocktail. I drank a bottle of whiskey, and ripped up a sheet, I then tried pouring a bottle of whiskey on the sheet, it didn't work. A couple of game days later I came across a gas can, I substituted the whiskey for gas, and 'lo and behold a molotov was created. These are the kind of possibilities that will keep you coming back forever. Everything makes sense.

There are no shortage of oh ♥♥♥♥ I better drink some bleach because I'm about to turn in to a zombie" moments

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is absolutley amazing - and it's in alpha.
It's well worth the fourteen dollars, I've spent pretty much all of my free time in the game collecting loot, building fortifications, roleplaying and managing wounds and infections. This game has so many elements including farming, protecting oneself and tending to injuries. There are traits that impact your game experience and zombies that are a threat but possible to take down in small groups (even multiple zombies!).
I am so proud of the developers. After my WarZ experience I went in gritting my teeth but I am so pleasantly surprised. This has literally edged its way to the top of my favorite game list and is helping me so much in coping with real life stress and whatnot.
I play the multiplayer all the time and love a good roleplay so message me if you do too!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hey everyone... I'm a big fan of zombies and I heard about Project Zomboid on a website and it sounded really appealing to me. I figured after finding it on Steam I'd try out the demo.... after dodging some zombies , opening the door to a gun shop and being confronted with the first zombie I ever fought I was hooked... Since then I`ve bought the game and played it the last couple of days, and it`s amazing.... the zombies can be avoided if you remain unseen and unheard but if one sees you its best to fight him rather than run because although you can out-run them, you``ll have a horde following you if you do....

There`s so much you can do in the game that I haven`t done yet, I plan on collecting supplies and building a base in the woods away from the city eventually... My only advice is to keep playing this game, practise different techniques until you find what works best for you, and if you find it too hard play it in Sandbox mode which allows you to set up the setting to low population zombies (which still is a lot), Etc.

This game has so much to offer, you can honestly feel the experience of survival in this zombie apacolypse, and its not even the finished result yet, in my opinion it`s definitely stable enough to play, has multiplayer option and one day will have a lot more than it does now including hunting, driving and looting cars, etc.

If you`re thinking about buying this game play the demo, and if you`re intrigued, buy it while it`s still early access, it`ll be worth a lot more in the future... its a good deal, you get updated everytime they add something even after buying the game, and it runs on low requirements computers as long as it has a decent graphics card, 1-2 gb ram and the hard drive space required, I definitely recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

UPDATED: 29/06/14

I've come back to this game again recently after taking a 6-month break or so (I find this is the best way to enjoy Early Access games) and I feel like it's improved markedly since my last review.

Project Zomboid is best described as 'DayZ meets classic Fallout' - if that's something that appeals to you (and it should!), then I can recommend this game wholeheartedly. In previous incarnations, the game was undeniably promising but very rough round the edges, meaning the absorbing battle against the environment and the monsters that inhabit it was punctuated with jarring bugs and glitches like falling through stairs, walking straight through walls and so on.
Many of the more troublesome gremlins have been zapped, and while there are still a few that pop up from time to time, the game is a lot less likely to do something utterly bizarre, and a lot more likely to kill you with cold, hard logic and survival elements.

The developers have handled the release fairly well, providing steady and worthwhile updates whilst continuing to listen to their community and prioritising the issues that matter most to the fans (stability and the addition of multiplayer). This has resulted in a game that I feel a lot more players would consider 'truly' playable and could sink many hours into, even in its current state.

There IS still a long way to go - NPCs seem like they're still a way off, and it's odd to see entire towns almost perfectly modelled, but without a single car in sight - wrecked or otherwise. These things will no doubt be sorted in time - the developers have proven over the past 12 months on Steam that they are happy to take their time working on things until they're ready rather than risking adding things too early and bringing in a host of bugs and issues.

Overall:

Fun?: Yes
Any Game-Breaking Issues?: Not really game-breaking, but it's not finished.
Worth the Price of Admission?: Yes.

============================================================================
ORIGINAL REVIEW:

First things first - I've been playing Project Zomboid since I first learned about it on Steam Greenlight way back when it was one of the flagship titles, so obviously the game-time in Steam doesn't really reflect that. Just for disclosure there. :)

Anyway, onto the game, and the first question you're going to want to know is 'is it worth it?'

And annoyingly, it's kind of difficult to answer right now. Let's get this out of the way right now - in its CURRENT STATE, Zomboid is bug-riddled and missing many key features. If you're buying it right now (November 2013), you need to understand that this is absolutely an Alpha - entire chunks of the game simply aren't there right now, in particular NPCs.
It's also clunky to control, has a learning curve that's almost Dwarf Fortress-esque in its steepness, and occasionally difficult to navigate.

But the one thing that keeps me coming back and that convinced me to part with my money in the first place is the potential. It's not the 'War Z' potential where the devs are making grand promises with absolutely no idea how on earth they're going to keep them - the basics are in there: the map is freaking enormous, and it's gloriously detailed. The zombie behaviour is excellent - individually they're not a threat, but make a loud noise or stumble into a horde and you're in a whole WORLD of trouble. The parts of the game that are complete show an attention to detail and that little spark of inspiration that give the player confidence that whatever's being promised/worked on is going to arrive, and when it does, it'll be awesome.

So to conclude, although it's often banded about these days, it's more true than most in the case of Project Zomboid - when you hand over your £9.99 (or regional equivalent, I guess!), you're buying the game it's GOING to be, not the game it is right now. If you're not convinced that this is a gamble worth taking, you might be better off waiting six months for the game to take a little more shape, but you should be aware that the price will likely creep up again slightly, as the developers have confirmed that they want to reward early adopters by offering it to them for less than 'full price', whatever that may end up being.

Fun to Play?: Yes
Any Gamebreaking issues?: Lots
Worth the admission price?: Depends on your patience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Have you ever seen the Walking Dead? Most of you have. Let me say, if you think you could survive better than some of the characters in the walking dead, this game is your challenge. You have to fight numerous zombies, I have yet to have a save where i have not killed one zombie. You have to scavenge through the city trying to be unoticed the mass amounts of hordes of zombies and find what little food there is left. Eventually the zombies will find your safehouse, so you need to make defenses. you need to barricade your windows, build walls, and maybe build more rooms and crates for storage. eventually, the city will run out of food, so you need to either get the supplies to go fishing, or trap mice and rats and make a campfire to cook them. This game is the real deal. This will test your survivability. This is your chance to prove you can do it. This is the end.
---
OLD REVIEW:
If you like zombie games, and games that require a little bit of strategy and skill, this is the game for you. at first when i saw this game, and i admit, i thought it was stupid. My best friend had showed it to me, and my first thoughts were that its stupid. i watched him play it anyway because i like to give games a chance. as i saw all of the techniques he used, it started to change my mind a little bit.  then i saw that in this game, you can barricade windows, build walls and barrels to collect rain in for when the water goes out, and saw that you can even farm food and cook food like steak, chicken, and meat patties, my opinion completley changed. This, is probably the most realistic zombie game that i have ever seen and/or played. this game will very soonly have multiplayer and NPC's. I have played this for 25 hrs. on steam record and i am not even close to bored with it. I HIGHLY RECCOMEND THIS GAME.
-
UPDATE 12/7/2014
i've had this game for almost a year now, and i am still very happy with my purchase. this game is slow paced, and i took about a 4 month break from it because i got some other games that i was interested in, and to be honest, i got bored of this game. after a few updates had come out for the game, including a multiplayer update, (which i play on public servers a lot) and some graphic changes, including 3D models that look amazing, FPS optimization, and the ability to see if things are in shelves (which sounds like nothing, but before everything looked empty even if you had like 24 items on it) i came back to this game yesterday, and put about 15 hours into it since. This game is very fun, especially if you get a nice safehouse running with reinforced walls and such. well, thanks for reading my review, if you have any questions, let me know by commenting, and i will do my best to respond ASAP! Have a good day, and i hope that if you choose to purchase this game, you get many hours out of it!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game, which is inspired by max brooks book is really enjoyable in singleplayer, but in co-op with 3 friends it shows its flaws. For early acces, the game is deep and exciting but on the other hand it has few bugs as a movement of zombies (they sometimes stop and freeze around obstacles) and gunshots (which triggers zombie migration) goes in loops from time to time. Game itself contains everything what you can expect from this genre: making a shelter, scavenging supplies, battling a huge numbers of zombies and progress of your character. I´m really looking forward to next updates which adds more content and make the game even better. And a little advice for newbies: when you find a shotgun, never shoot with it near any city (it´s suicide).

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe openended nature of this game makes it special. You can use the sandbox feature to create the zombie survival mode of your choice. reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is amazing. When I first saw it on ImmortalHD's channel I thought it was a semi decent game that would be fun to play. Little did I know it would evolve into what it is now. This game has come along way with the addition of an advanced medical system and the (hopefully soon to be) addition of NPCs.

Pros:

- Interesting. Can keep you immersed if played properly for days
- One of the MOST realistic survival simulators out there. (Might not be like DayZ, but in terms of survival it is)

Cons:

- Little boring on single player if you are new (I prefer multiplayer experiences)

Little Multiplayer Story:

Me and my friend were playing in a server. We decided to head to the hunting lodge up in West Point (That's where we thought the others in the game would be at) and found it to be empty of other players. We searched through the building to find a shotgun and a few shells. I was told to keep watch since I had no weapons and out of the corner of my eye I saw two men outside fighting off zombies. I screamed to my friend THEY'RE OUTSIDE!! HURRY! I SEE THEM! THERE ARE PEOPLE OUT THERE!!" He came to the door only to bust out screaming shooting blindly at them. One was gunned down in the process and the other took a severe wound to his chest. I picked up his weapon and we followed him into the woods. We assume he bled out... but we will never know to this day.

10/10 would search again"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

THE Zombie Survival game.

From one playthough, I can already see that Project Zomboid is just unforgiving, rewarding your impatience with a group of zombies pounding on the door of a closet that you desperately tried to hide yourself in whilst you crafted a molotov cocktail on the spot so you could burn down your entire house, taking as many zombies as you could with you.

Seriously, though. If you happen to accidentally take a wrong turn or make a noise too loud, you can end up being bitten, and as soon as you're bitten, you genuinely die. Being bitten will actually progress into zombification (if that's the word). You've gotta choose your own safehouse, build your own defenses and scavenge for food yourself. The game does nothing for you except choose a spawn location. After that, the world is your metaphorical oyster!

Just one violent, dark, flesh-eating oyster... Let's stick with that.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is great.  I have yet to really delve into the multiplayer aspect of it much, but just even going solo is a lot of fun, and the game continues to impress with each update.  You really feel alone and helpless in this game as you run around and try to loot all you possibly can while you cross your fingers and pray for the items/tools/weapons you need to sustain yourself for just one more day.  The aspect I really love in this game is how you can set how early on the infection has been in effect.  You can set it early on so there's still indoor plumbing for easy access to water and electricity, or much later on during the infection where electricity is shut off and you rely on generators or just roughing it, and water being had from stockpiling water bottles or collecting rainwater in barrels.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is another one of those games that I'm sure I'll give a thumbs up to, but only once the developers starts fixing the major issues. Don't get me wrong, this is a good game, but development is rather slow but the bigger problem is that the developers don't prioritise things that most players are complaining about. My major concerns are:

-The game is difficult to get into for new players. There is a small survival guide but really you will need to go to the online wiki and online map if you are to have any hope of surviving. There should be much more in game help and tooltips, especially with regard to crafting.
- There really should be an in-game map (or an option to turn it on). It makes no sense that your character who is living in the town has no idea what the layout of the town is. I mean there is already an online map and everybody seems to be using it so the only reason for the developers not to include it is because they can't be bothered.

This is not a bad game, I bought it and it is a nice experience for 15$. I just wish the developers would stop wasting their time on things like making the game map bigger while there are other more pressing issues to sort out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Project Zomboid is pretty much your typical zombie survival game.

First of all, any fans of being a Bandit in Dayz. This game is not for you.

Now that's out of the way Project Zombiod is a 2D zombie survival game. Its simple you wake up in a house in a large town split into two districts. You search around the houses cupboards, draws and even the fridge for supply's. Now you go to the window and see that their are many other house's around you probabaly containing even more loot. You open your front door and look out and see no sigh of trouble. You walk over to the house and find that the front door is locked. You walk around the side and open the window. You enter the house and start to look around. You manage to find yourself a new crowbar to use as a weapon. You also use a plastic bag to help you hold more food. You walk up the stairs and see a Zombie jump out at you. You beat it to death but notice that your character is now worried and frightened. You walk back to your house but as you open the front door a zombie sneaks up from behind and attacks you. You spin around, pull out your crowbar and beat it to death.

You walk inside than treat yourself to a nice cold TV Dinner. 15 minutes later you get sick and die. Because you didnt cook the food.

That was my first 20 Minutes in project zomboid and it made an impression. Sure its a simple survival zombie game but its felt real. The scaverging is where the games best moments are. Breaking into houses and carfully moving from room to room, collecting bed sheets to put on the windows as curtains back home so Zombies arn't attracted to the light.

The game plays like any basic 2D game. Just move and click. You have two menus which display your inventory and whats around you. It is very basic in that way. But its how your character is and feels that works well. If you get attacked by a zombie your player will become panicked and won't be as accurate with his hits. Or if your at your base waiting around or reading about new skills your chacter will become bored which can lead to the charcter being un-happy. The weapons are basic. You just swing your bat in the direction and the target and it will hit it. Or if you have a gun its pre much auto-lock. No skill is required you just look,shoot and you hit your target. Their are no cars in the game so your always walking which can become repative and boring. The game is fair from realistc but feels real in a way that you always find stuff in places where you would expect stuff to be. Unlike in Dayz where you find stuff lying on the floor. Here you look in draws,shelfs and fridges to find loot. I love entering new houses or areas not knowing what is going to be there.

The game isn't extremly easy. If you find yourself in a horde of zombies, to put it nicely. You're ♥♥♥♥ed. Zombies are a threat even though they can be taken down by one shot at times with a gun, zombies will hear this shot and close in on you. Once me and my friend were trying to loot a bank, we ran into the parking lot to find a horde of zombies waiting for us. We panicked smashed the window and jumped inside. I lost sight of my friend as 4 zombies that were already in the building closed in on me. I freaked out, pulled out my pistol and shot all 4. Worst decison of my life. Now zombies were flodding in, smashing windows  and breaking down the door's. As I had now discoverd my friend had left me for dead. I ran upstairs and tried to find a new way out and had no luck. As I tried to open a window to see if I could climb out. Zombies snuck up behind me and started attacking me. Already injuired I was dead in seconds. The game isn't easy seeing that zombies are easily attracted to noise and you can only see a small distance where your chacter is facing. The game can be hard on your own. But play it right or with friends and you will grasp it.

Now eventually you will find yourself sellting down and buliding a base. Base building consits of two things, Physical Bulding and Farming. You can build walls to fortify your house and make a large farming area that you have to fertilise and water. It's basic but it works. Farming is also a great idea because eventually all water and power supply stops. So you cant keep your food in the fridge or drink water from the tap.

Once you have a base I can find the game can begin to get repatative and boring. Eventually I found myself repeating the same thing. Going out and scaving as much as I can than bring it home. With the occasional farm. That is where the game really lacks. It get's boring. Their's no big multipalyer too. Sure you can join  populated severs but its just a cluster-♥♥♥♥. In the single player theirs no AI, no objectives, no events or anything like that. I wish their was the occasional moment when you run into a gang of AI and have a all out war. Or find other bases to break into or raid. Or maybe make a town and have AI work in it. All this can be added and I wish it will. Im sure AI will be added at some point with other features because right now after a while the game gets boring. But that is a matter of hours in. You can always start a new life fresh on your own or with friends and do it all again.

The music in the game is great I have to say.

THE VERDICT:

Pros:
-Zombie AI works great
-Scavaging is fun
- Looks fresh and new
-Good fun with friends
-Feels real but not too real
-Base building

Cons:
-Not a whole lot to it
-Gets repeative after a while
-No AI makes the only threat zombies
-Big severs don't work

RATING: 8/10

The game is worth the price by a mile. I know the game is in early acceses so they will add new things and the game will get even better and the score would probably be bosted up to and 8 or maybe even a 9. But for now it's diffently worth it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I would say if you want to get more of a single player experience with a zombie survival game then this is the game you want to get. There are a multitude of ways to customise your game before you play. From the type of game, time, character settings, traits, zombie movement and amount etc. Never one game will be the same. With the addition of multiplayer in the future and a lot of planned features you can see on the store page, this is definitely a great purchase.

As to how this game plays, it is not a walk in the park. This game is true survival at heart and you can't be complacent and the more risks you take, the more likely you are to die. Some ways I have died have been from not clearing a house before looting, getting cornered by a horde inside a house and also outside, eating rotten vegetable, getting sick from being out in the rain too much, falling off the stairs (early beta), not making sure a zombie on the ground is dead, walking through a forest and then suddenly getting set on by a horde, leaving the lights on or window open for visibility, getting shot by an npc (early beta), attacking a zombie on the road only to attact more further down it, burning the house down by leaving the oven on. Longest I've lived for was 10 days.

I'm still new to this game and have heard about the farming, building and crafting available to build defences and to hold out against a moving zombie horde. Great game and definitely would recommend it to friends.

Looting houses, hospitals, churches, markets, shopping centres, schools, sheds, cabbins, apartments, restaurants, gp centre, warehouses, commercial buildings what more can you ask for?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A lot of zombie games share a common flaw. Zombies serve only as target practice. The aspect of prolonged survival in a post apocalyptic world is pretty much ignored, other than the occassional reference or scene. The concept of rebuilding in this new world is also forgotten. You just go from point A to B and shoot some zombies, that's it. And then there's Project Zomboid. You get to shoot zombies (bad idea!), but you also get the chance to rebuild. Find a good spot, build a wall and before you know it, you've got your own base to defend.

Of course, it's not that easy, but it should give a good idea. The game has carpentry, farming and most recently even hunting was added (to an extent). Which brings me to the second point. The company constantly adds more content. It's a good habit, one I hope to keep seeing for a long time.

So I definitely recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do you want a game to pick up and play? Do you want a game to just have a quick thirty minutes of play? Well move along because this game will take more time than you have to give.

Family? Girlfriend? Career? None of them will matter once you start playing this immersive, addictive and terrifying survival horror. If you want to know how I managed to pull myself away long enough to write this review, well I'll tell you. I had a family, girlfriend and career but I murdered them all just so I could play this game without being interrupted. They sent me to prison of course and now I'm out. One of the conditions is that I can never play Project Zomboid again. So it's up to you my brethren enjoy my addiction by proxy for me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Reviewing at Alpha Stage: I took a quick look at the pictures and one video, noticed a demo was shared to us the consumer I decided to give it a shot.

Demo: The demo starts you off as a female hidden away, you're bitten which allows you to play for a couple of days before becoming a zombie, this is a tipical demo feature which stops you from playing the game for free and thinking that is all it. The demo gave me a strong impression on what it is capable of so I decided to buy it for a low cost compared to other indie games.

The Alpha: Bugs, glitches, crashes will happen in every single alpha so I tend to ignore these a little whiles doing a review unless it is a major issue which it is not and I am happy to continue this review.

The main menu is brilliant, the lightning flashes with the music kicking in that reveals a hidden dark secret to the two characters on screen, you have three game modes Survival, Last Stand, Sandbox.

Survival; As the game is meant to be, you create your character with its pros and cons, you start in  one out of two worlds which random generates items and your starting area which opens your eyes up and scares you from roaming too far in the early stage, you need to keep fed, watered, fit and infection free! If you're a zombie fan then playing this is logical, play it as a movie and real life scenerios for survival and you will not have a problem on keeping alive....until you meet zombies, they are slow, fast, weak and strong...some walk, some run, some crawls, they're all attracted to smell of blood dripping, sound and sight which creates or breaks hordes up.

Sandbox; just like survival but you're in control for a while on what the world can be like for zombies, make them weak or super hard.

Laststand: You're holding out aslong as you can before death, there is only one way to win.... stand and defend as long as you can.....Winning is death in my eyes.

Graphics might look weak to you but they really fit the game well, sounds are brilliant from zombie growls, sounds of guns, alarms, windows smasing, doors breaking and more.

For an Alpha it is well done for its pre-release, if you can not hack bugs, crashes, glitches then wait until people report less and less.


6.6 rating for alpha. I will review it once again when the game has improved to be held by its title on its own which will be on my site.

YES I will recommend it to my friends. (Playing it on a IMAC OSX Snow Leapod.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome game.  I've long been a fan of the zombie genre (classic Romero stuff), and this game doesn't disappoint.  Most realistic 'zombie sim' I've ever seen.  It doesn't pretend there's a happy ending...you see how long you can hold out in the Z-Apocalypse.

Beta stage but still VERY playable and VERY fun.  I literally can only play in short spurts as it's almost too scary in terms of realism.  Zombies can be deadly,  and it's generally safer to avoid them.  Collect food, gather water (the waterworks WILL fail after some time), and establish a safe(r) place to sleep and store your ransacked goods.   Try the free demo...you'll be hooked :-) .

Good luck!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of the few real survival games out there/here. You don't win this game, you just get to survive a while longer each time you start a new game. There's no happy ending for you characters.

Bought after playing the demo for an hour, spent the next 2 days playing it almost non-stop. It's Alpha at the moment so there are many bugs but the roadmap for the game looks very promising. And there's also a nice modding community on the forums where you can find all sorts of mods to make survival easier/harder.
