reviewText:
Early Access Review

For it to still be in Alpha phase (Period)* and to impress me this much. Literally one of the funnest games I've played in a long time, with the survival aspect challenging you to constantly be on the move and have a sharp eye for the items you need to cover your way through the next few days and worst case scenarios of the zombie apocolypse. Innovating the diablo style point of view, but incorporating an elder scrolls style of detail of items, item creation and it even has a dash of the minecraft sandbox building ability/freedom.

This game really flows and has hours, days and weeks worth of gameplay.

-With game changing aspects including perspective of your character(you can only see what your character would see, then the rest is a fog of war style), which I found was so emersive and really kept me on my toes everywhere, it makes going around corners, going into houses, bathrooms and forests a real edge of your seat experience, my heart still gets pumping everytime I enter a new house.

-Having to take care of your character is one of the most important things to worry about in the zombie apocolypse, he/she can get thirsty, hungry, scared, injured, bored, cold, wet, sick, etc. All of these have negative effects if you don't tend to them, be it less perceptive; so it's harder to hear or see the zombies approach you, your character could get to cold or wet whilst outside from the different seasons or rainy weather; ending up getting sick and begin to sneeze and cough, which in turn would attract more zombies.

-Through a rough and tumble with some zombies, you may require medical attention, luckly enough; you can make bandages out of clothes and sheets you may find. Also.. it never hurts to hit the medicine cabinet in the bathroom to see if they have any painkillers or vitamins they didn't need/get to use. There is also a medical centre.. some where.

-Once you have gathered enough supplies to get you by you may look at fortifying your stronghold; with water collecting barrels, fences, window barracades, sheet rope so you can make a quick exit if a horde of zombies have just busted in to see the new digs. But I guess if you spawn in the right location you could start fortifying straight away, but prioritize in the first few days-weeks on food and water..

-You can set up a farm, once you get the few neccesary components  you can begin to set up your own sustainable lifestyle in which you would never have to go out for supplies and just live off your own land.. but be careful, because the hordes do wander. You may think hey, i'll have my fridge and sink... i'll be fine. No, no you won't. The power and water gets cut off after a few weeks(maybe months if you're lucky), just to get you settled in.

-Meta game has been so much fun for me through this game, sometimes you'll hear a gun go off a few houses down, an army chopper goes over doing a few laps attracting zombies to the area, and they're even going to impliment NPC's within the coming months to make it a more thrilling and unexpected experience.

-All the little things really get me smiling with this game. There is so many things you can do, for eg;
You can use, anything from bottles, cups, mugs, cooking pots and others so you can store water for later, you can do great things once you find the specific tools required for that job, like cutting trees with an axe, then using a saw to cut planks, hammer and nails for your building needs. Using sheets to break line of sight for when you are trundling around your safe house, some houses have alarm systems which can be a god send, or a death sentence..

I am only scraping the surface of this game and it really has blown me away as to how intricate and detailed the develpoers have crafted this game, I am still learning more and more everytime I play it and it will only get better from here, with so much more to come, might as well hop on now..
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Amazing game. If u liked the feel of the old school Ultima Online...Its like that...with zombies. lol
Lots of Depth. Tons to do ( or more like worry bout) Infections, water, medical problems, food, bandits, supplies, shelter, and oh ya... Zombies.

Multiplayer is a blast.
Base Building is fun!
Zombies hide in houses and behind doors and in bathrooms. So u gotta clear a house throughly before bedding down!
Nerve Wracking.

Worth every penny. The developers are eager and involved. They release patches almost weekly.
Vehicles are planned very soon and so are intelligent AI NPCS!

Only con I have about the game is the night time in houses are verrrry dark ( like they should be ) But I just wish they had a gamma or brightness slider.

Game is kinda intimidating at first because of the meticulousness of the controls and abilities. The developers are really sticklers for the details! (which i like ) But that also means theres a bit of learning curve to over come first. I suggest maybe watching youtube videos / tutorials to help get started. But after you learn the keys....Its no problem!

BUY IT!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros:
The only game on the market that deserves the classification zombie survival simulator". A lot of games that call themselves survival simulators
date: aren't much more than shooters with rudimentary crafting elements thrown in. Project zomboid on the other hand really contains very extensive survival elements
recommended:
from physical to psychological effects and needs to elaborate crafting mechanics.

Cons:
There are some small bugs and at some points I had to restart the game. Didn't bother me too much. On OSX it runs A LOT more stable for me though
hoursPlayed: than on Windows 7. No idea why. From a design standpoint I really miss an optional save function. It is really fun to play whit to constant fear of death for some hours - but then it has gotten old for me. After surviving for about 30 days
voteText: I started to copy the save-games folder all the time
helpfulPercent: cause I wanted to experiment with the crafting and expand my characters skills. Sure you can return to your buldings with a new character but why not include an optional save function when I can copy the save games folder anway. Some people will dislike this statement

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Can't say enough about this game. Simply amazing. It's probably the best zombie sim you will play. I bought this game over a year ago on Desura and have enjoyed it since (with and with out bugs). There is a lot to deal with. Unlike Day Z you don't have to worry about other players. This is great because it puts the focus on survival and zombies. The game will have co op and multiplayer later from what I understand. The game itself is open world so you get dropped in and have to scavange and fend for yourself. One of the first things you will probably want to do is establish some sort of safe house. From there what you do is entirely up to you. You can choose to loot nearby buildings, kill zombies, look for other NPC's, build a farm,  etc.

The game has a fairly deep building system. it works kind of like Dead Rising except not as crazy. You can grab a bat and put it together with nails to form a nailed bat or you can combine liqour with a rag for molotov cocktails. The building system also extends to safe houses. You can barricade doors, windows, etc. This is vital in case your house gets hit by a zombie horde. Most safe houses don't stay safe for long. There are a lot of factors that can put your home in danger. Looter NPC's making too much noise and attracting zombies are just a few of the dangers.

You can't just stay in your safe house however, eventually hunger and other factors set in. Your character is susceptible to things ranging from boredom to sleep deprivation. Some of these things can be curbed a bit because the game offers a nice character creation system. You can invest in things like courage to make yuor character less likely to freak out during a zombie fight. You can also choos to make him a better runner, etc. This seems generic but there is a neat little twist. For every good" trait you choose you must balance it out with a "bad" trait. This prevents you from making a super powerful character. Some traits have a higher cost than others and this really creates a balanced and unique character creation system.

One of the things I really enjoyed about this game is the fact that you can adjust the zombies. You can make them Romero style (slow) or 28 Days Later (runners). You can also adjust minute things like infection spreading. This is simply fantastic since it gives you the ability to play with different zombie types. This isn't the only thing you can change however. This game has a great modding community and the developers seem to support modding for this game heavily. There are already a bunch of great mods out for this game and I would highly suggest you try some out.

One of the things I didn't like about the game is the inventory system. You need to carry bags to lighten your carry weight. The more you have on your body the slower you move. Makes sense and a great system used in other games.  Different bags have different carry capacity. The problem I had with this is that while you are out and about you really want to carry a minimum set of things (weapons
recommended:
etc). While out scavenging you may have to find some where to sleep for the night or may need some supplies. Carrying items in different bags seems a bit cumbersome. I understand the need for the bags but I feel like it could be done a little better.

Over all this game has a lot going for it and I was very excited when it was green lit on Steam. If you want a nice variety in zombie simulation you should give this game a try. It has a lot going for it and you can definitely see the developers have a lot of love for the community and zombie fans in general.

+ Great open world
+ Amazing simulator
+ Good  customization
+ Lots of options for different style of gameplay

- Not so awesome inventory system.

4.5/5"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Project Zomboid is Day Z meets Minecraft in a 2D isometric world. Still in alpha, but with plenty of game play to keep players entertained for hours, Project Zomboid drops you in the middle of a suburban landscape as the sole (in the current build at least) survivor of a classic zombie outbreak. You will die, this is inevitable. The question (and objective) the game poses is: how long will you survive?

Surviving isn't as simple as staying indoors and out of sight however. Like a normal person you have needs. Hunger, thirst, sleep, and entertainment are periodic needs that must be fulfilled lest you risk your health and sanity. Satisfying these needs will require venturing outside and scavenging for supplies. At first it all seems so simple: find some food to eat, maybe some magazines to read and you're all set, water's still coming out of the tap after all and as long as the window shades are closed no zombie will come looking for you, that is until one follows you home and starts pounding on the window.

Maybe he'll just go away" you think
date: but before you can act the window is broken and the zombie is inside. Run or fight
recommended: those are your options. You've spent too long gathering supplies to run and you're too tired to get very far so you're going to have to fight
hoursPlayed: but with what? Quick! To the counter! The kitchen knife. You grab the knife just in time and violently stab the intruder over and over before finally it succumbs.\n\nMaybe the house isn't as secure as you thought and now the window is broken. Perhaps if you had a hammer
voteText: some boards
helpfulPercent: and nails you could barricade it up. If you're going to head out to find these things however you'll need a better weapon and you'll have to find that too. Maybe surviving isn't going to be so easy afterall."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Definitely one of the best Zombie games that i have ever played. It was also one of the first Indie games that I ever purchased. The game challenges you to survive for as long as possible, At first, the world is very similar to how it would be without zombies, only they are roaming outside. But as you survive, the electricity shuts off, lights no longer work. You must roam with a flashlight to cut through the dark Mudlraugh wilderness. Then the water shuts off, you must collect water bottles, pop bottles. Or construct a barrel to store some rain water. All while evading hordes of zombies, and risking infection in all of your close quarter battles. You are a regular survivor, every scratch and bite has a chance to turn you into a moaning, bloody mess. Sometimes a frying pan isnt enough to save you when zombies are breaking in through every entrance of your shelter. PZ is updated roughly every couple weeks, and the devs are about to finish up the new engine that will make the game run much smoother again, along with adding NPCs and the story again soon, which were removed so they could be revamped to fit all of the new changes in the game. The game is definitely worth the $15, as i have far more hours on it than almost any commercial game, and the moaning of zombies is calling you to fight or die. However, a warning, when you get insanely addicted to this, and want more zombies, you will be disappointed by the other games.

Visuals - 9 for what its meant to be and an Indie
Sound/Music - 10, scary moaning and awesome soundtrack
Story - Not back in place
Gameplay - 10

EDIT: Game is getting lots of updates, they're putting the new 3D engine in and its looking fantastic!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I absolutely love this game.
Admittedly I had torrented this game before they implemented multiplayer. (I didn't want to buy a game so early in development, sorry Zomboid Devs :C ) I finally have picked up a copy, and convinced a couple friends to do so as well.
I've easily put atleast 60 hours into v27 with a group of 5 friends including myself.

The multiplayer is fantastic, and in it's current state it is well worth the pricetag.
If I had to compare this to any other game, it'd of course have to be DayZ, HOWEVER I would play this over that any day.
Although not as amazing graphics wise, there is so many more things you can do in Project Zomboid that you can't in DayZ.
It's more immersive, and when it's night in-game, this actually gets terrifying. DayZ, not so much.

They plan on adding improved hunting, vehicles, and to readd and improve the NPC's(Can't wait!)
and once they do that, you'd have to be a zombie not to buy this game.

In it's current ALPHA state 8/10, when they add NPC's again 10/10.
Buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Started my adventure as Bottas Waters, a former construction worker with a low-tolerance of alcoholic beverages.
Found some food, other basic supplies and a fork to use as a weapon.
I ventured outside, and found my neighbours house sitting empty across the street. Unfortunately, his doors were locked, so I smashed the window and entered. A zombie came out a closet so I stabbed it in the eye with a fork and it died, but my fork broke too.
I then found a rolling pin, and used that as a weapon from thereon out.
Looted some more cupboards, and noticed my character was getting slightly thirsty, so this was my first major introduction into the true survival aspects of this game. Fortunately, I had a drink in my inventory.
Misclicked, drank bleach and died.
10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

They're working on it constantly, and it keeps getting better. Single player's great right now, but I don't recommend multiplayer yet.

Multiplayer's not great yet, because it lacks a speed-time feature. At night time, it's hard to see. If you don't want your character to roam around in the dark, then you have to wait for nighttime to slowly pass. You get to sit and stare as your character stands around in the dark, because your character doesn't sleep and you can't fast-forward. In single-player, this isn't a problem. You get sleepy, go to bed, and time speeds while you sleep. You can also fast-forward time whenever you want to. This means that you can focus on playing, and avoid nighttime. You can also avoid having to sit and wait for rain to stop, too. The developers have been good about polishing the game, and it keeps shining. So, multiplayer will likely be fixed in the future. However, for now, multiplayer's not great.

Single-player is fun already. The world has a nice sandbox feel to it. You can zoom in close or keep the camera far out, which allows for a nice, customizable view. There are many items to find, and the developers keep adding in more. The map has a large area to explore, and the developers keep adding more to it, too. You can cook, build, garden and, apparently, fish. (I still haven't gotten around to fishing.) Hunting's another new thing.

The only issue I have with it is that its gotten easy for me, but this is after dozens of hours of playing it. (Once you get into a rhythm with an axe and a shotgun, zombies are less intimidating.) And it's still fun anyway. I'll gather up shotgun shells and corral zombies, because there's a certain joy to thinning out the horde while zigging and zagging between the undead. I'm looking forward to when NPCs are added back in, and for multiplayer to be improved. Overall, this is a good game that keeps getting better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Project Zomboid is Day Z meets Minecraft in a 2D isometric world. Still in alpha, but with plenty of game play to keep players entertained for hours, Project Zomboid drops you in the middle of a suburban landscape as the sole (in the current build at least) survivor of a classic zombie outbreak. You will die, this is inevitable. The question (and objective) the game poses is: how long will you survive?

Surviving isn't as simple as staying indoors and out of sight however. Like a normal person you have needs. Hunger, thirst, sleep, and entertainment are periodic needs that must be fulfilled lest you risk your health and sanity. Satisfying these needs will require venturing outside and scavenging for supplies. At first it all seems so simple: find some food to eat, maybe some magazines to read and you're all set, water's still coming out of the tap after all and as long as the window shades are closed no zombie will come looking for you, that is until one follows you home and starts pounding on the window.

Maybe he'll just go away" you think
date: but before you can act the window is broken and the zombie is inside. Run or fight
recommended: those are your options. You've spent too long gathering supplies to run and you're too tired to get very far so you're going to have to fight
hoursPlayed: but with what? Quick! To the counter! The kitchen knife. You grab the knife just in time and violently stab the intruder over and over before finally it succumbs.\n\nMaybe the house isn't as secure as you thought and now the window is broken. Perhaps if you had a hammer

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let's start off by saying this game is in no sense casual, it is for the hardcore zombie genre fans who want a challenge and who have been looking for a realistic zombie apocalypse simulator. I for one have been on the search for a zombie game that put all the elements of its predecessors into one perfect representation. From helpful but not over the top skills to the building that is not obnoxious but gives you versatility and creativity to create the zombie safe house or fort of your dreams.

This game also makes you control your charter completely from getting sick to going insane; you must not only build a base and survive by eating but taking care of your charter as if he were yourself. At first the game mechanics and controls may seem foreign but once you sit down and get to know them, they are very fluent. Talking more about the crafting system and various items in the game, there is not a single item in the game that does not have a use at this point, this brilliant plan of having every item in the game have its own specific role gives this game an immersion level like no other. Yes the graphics are not HD, but they execute the feeling and atmosphere of the game flawlessly, and could have been done no other way to give the game the feel that is has, on top of the amazing sound track that is simple and not too much.  The top down type gameplay with all the weird" black space may seem odd and even annoying at first glance
date: but once you sink your teeth into this game and get familiar with the load out
recommended: it’s used and executed perfectly to again give an immersion level like no other.  I will say this
hoursPlayed: PZ is a game that is absolutely brutal and will kick you down and keep you there unless you play through it and get familiar with the game. Do not go into this game thinking you will live forever and never die.  One little scratch or run in with a zombie or two maybe even hordes of hundreds just because you shot your gun can be the end of you
voteText: after all the game tells you during the load screen that this  your experience  is a story of how you died.  On top of everything so far there is an amazing modding community that are coming out with mods and different maps to play if you eventually get tired of playing the two stock maps

I would have to say that this game is best played with a friend for an even more enjoyable experience. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing this game for a little while now and I haven't written a review for it, so here it is.

Project Zomboid is an amazing zombie apocalypse simulator. As a fan of most zombie games, and especially open-world RPG's, I cannot begin to tell you how much I enjoyed this title.
Let me begin;

Pros:    Great graphics (if you're more into the retro look)
Gratifying gameplay (the game always offers something different, with TREMENDOUS replay value)
Sandbox mode, allowing you to customise how you want to play the game. You can change anything from the speed of zombies to their toughness, how often rare items come up, the temperature of the world, how fast the time progresses, what happens once you are bitten, and much, much more.
Realism. Of course, the game isn't completely realistic, however for a fictional zombie game it does an amazing job at keeping the game fairly realistic.
Character customisation. You're allowed to choose traits for your character which not only give you an advantage (or disadvantage) in the game, but also allow for roleplay. Again, I'd like to remind that there's tremendous replay value. Want to find out how well an overweight police officer would do in the zombie apocalypse? You got it. Curious about how well a lucky construction worker with a hearty appetite would do if zombies could sprint but were more fragile? You got that, too. There's a lot of space to try out different scenarios which is exactly what this game is about.
Randomness. The whole game relies on chance, since all the items generated and the location where you spawn are (usually) different with each playthrough, you are allowed to experience what the zombie apocalypse would be like in different scenarios. I saw reviews of this game where people complained about how the random generation aspect of the game ruins it, but I rather like it; you won't always have a shotgun and an axe around when the apocalypse starts, and you are certainly less likely to find ammo nearby. If you're out in the city when the apocalypse starts and you're surrounded from every direction, you should try to get out alive and not complain about it. You won't always be out in the countryside when it starts, and it just so happens that it's a simulator to allow you to experience what it'd be like. I guarantee you will not be in a reinforced safehouse stocked with guns and ammo and food, away from people and zombies at the time when the apocalypse starts. The randomness is part of the challenge and realism.
Play the game how you want to play it. Want to go from house to house, from store to store stacking up on resources and surviving day to day? Go for it. How about finding a good house (or any building) that looks easily defensible, fortifying it and stocking it up with non-perishables while you go out and gather materials for reinforcing the perimeter and starting a farm so you can live off the land? Maybe a mix of both but not heavily relying on either? What about finding as many weapons and as much ammo as you can and killing as many zombies in the shortest amount of time? The possibilities are endless.
The Developers are extremely dedicated to the project and have yet to disappoint me in any way. They are friendly and actually listen to what the community wants, and try to satisfy everyone. Of course, the only problem is that the team is rather small which means that they cannot work too fast, but I admire how well they have handled things thus far.
Frequent updates, with more and more features coming out. I really love the 3D models which were recently added, however I've yet to try the fishing. Features such as multiplayer are already available, and NPC's are planned for the future.
An immersing, dark atmosphere centred around loneliness and caring only for yourself. I've yet to play multiplayer and NPC's have yet to come, however currently the game places you in the middle of a wasteland where the only sources of entertainment and good food and the odd book or magazine once in a while. Your character is alone and must survive alone. Grab all the resources you can and run. You're never 100% safe in any given place, no matter how much you reinforce it. You will die eventually, and the only thing you can do is try to live the longest and most fulfilling life possible. The dark atmosphere isn't enough to scare you, however you will develop a bond with your character and every encounter with a zombie which doesn't go according to plan will cause you to jump slightly as there is enough chance in one second of the game to screw up - something you should be terrified of seeing as permadeath is a feature that is heavily emphasized.
I have yet to encounter any bugs, even after playing the game for a little while.
Any approach is a good approach, as long as it is executed properly. Continue fighting as the number of zombies increases, and your ammo decreases. Fight off as many as you can, and retreat, then reinforce all doors and windows and attack them from behind with an improvised Molotov cocktail. Push them back and slow them down, while attempting to run away as fast as possible. Lock yourself in a bathroom, board up the door, and drink a bottle of bleach from under the sink. Every action you take will have different consequences and depending on how well you play it out, it'll either get you killed or allow you to live for one more day. Every such encounter increases your knowledge and allows you to play for longer and longer with each playthrough.
I've never seen a game like it; the uniqueness really caught my eye.
Cons:    Rather monotonous at times, and hard to get into. There is no in-game tutorial and you are forced to learn everything yourself, either through playing or research. The tutorial is going to be implemented again soon, though.
The style is not for everyone, and may put some people off. Initially most of the difficulty comes from not knowing how to play the game. Make sure you know what you're buying; there is a free demo provided and a lot of videos and photos that cover what the game is like. Another good idea would be to check the wiki.
It's still in development, which is clearly indicated, so the game isn't as good as it will be. However, it's still an extremely excellent game, and is very satisfying to play at this stage of the development.


Overall, it the game I'm the most satisfied with buying, and I have never before been this happy to help out a team of developers. The work they do is amazing and I thoroughly enjoyed their game.
If you like open-world zombie games focused on survival rather than killing as many zombies as possible, then you should definitely invest in the game (or at the very least try out the demo)

11/10, highly recommend.

Ok, just to clarify, this game is not comeplete. The current build feels finished, but the game will have SO MUCH MORE when its finished. That being said, this game... is awesome. Singleplayer will give you endless hours of fun, but only if you have patience. Multiplayer is very fun, but i recomend at least playing the tutorial before you jump on some random server (No-one likes a noob who cant even feed themselves). Heres how my first multiplayer experience went down:
>spawn in
>begin looting spawn house
>another player spawns in
>player asks if i want to team
>short while later, me and my new found friend head out into the unforgiving streets of Westpoint
>after looting houses for about 10 minutes, we encounter another player
>now with the 3 of us, we decide to assault the police station (some dumbass got a horde stuck in it)
>5 minutes later, our newest friend gets eaten alive by said horde while trying to lead them away from us.
>after mourning his death for about 5 seconds, me and my remaining friend try to lose the horde chasing us in some houses.
>i get bit inside one of the houses
>decide to not tell friend
>while friend is fixing mouse, i die and become a zombie
>my zombified self bites my friend
>friend runs away yelling NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO" because i died
>the end

As you can see

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Project Zomboid has come a long way. The development staff has weekly updates to let you know what will be released and what is on the agenda. The gameplay is smooth and fun. This is a survival game at it's best. An immersive medical system and cooking system. Combat is being worked on to contain more moves and animations so it does feel a bit dull right now. The graphics are a top down, isometric look. Your character is customizable down to the skills they possess. As you play the game, your skills will level up and you can add points to certain skills, blunt and accuracy are an example of them under the melee skills. You will die eventually either due to carelessness or unproper planning. The game time can extends to days as your in game time spans years. With the new updates you can watch the world around you deteriorate. Radio broadcasts and in game events will keep you aware of how society is devolving.

Please buy this game and support these devs if these things interest you. In comparison to other games alpha releases this game ALONE stands the test of time with constant updates and dev to community transparency. This game WILL be updated and WILL become better. It already has a ton of content and will have more in the future from NPCs to new items in game, including cars.

10/10 would survive again for a year and die in the winter due to crop failure in my huge built up fortress

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've had this game since way back in 2011 and it is steadily coming along! The excelent team of devs with lots of community interaction assures frequent updates and added features.

My Pros:
*Every update makes the world more immersive.
*Certain events trigger certain music tracks that really get your blood pumping.
*Really drives in the feeling of despair.

My Cons: (Barely cons)
*Coming from mostly FPS games the isometric world took time to get used to.
*Shifting items between containers and your inventory takes time until you're used to it.
*I find myself struggling with the context menus, climbing in and out of windows, closing a window I just opened on accident, ect..
*I have to take breaks between plays because I get really worked up while playing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

They're working on it constantly, and it keeps getting better. Single player's great right now, but I don't recommend multiplayer yet.

Multiplayer's not great yet, because it lacks a speed-time feature. At night time, it's hard to see. If you don't want your character to roam around in the dark, then you have to wait for nighttime to slowly pass. You get to sit and stare as your character stands around in the dark, because your character doesn't sleep and you can't fast-forward. In single-player, this isn't a problem. You get sleepy, go to bed, and time speeds while you sleep. You can also fast-forward time whenever you want to. This means that you can focus on playing, and avoid nighttime. You can also avoid having to sit and wait for rain to stop, too. The developers have been good about polishing the game, and it keeps shining. So, multiplayer will likely be fixed in the future. However, for now, multiplayer's not great.

Single-player is fun already. The world has a nice sandbox feel to it. You can zoom in close or keep the camera far out, which allows for a nice, customizable view. There are many items to find, and the developers keep adding in more. The map has a large area to explore, and the developers keep adding more to it, too. You can cook, build, garden and, apparently, fish. (I still haven't gotten around to fishing.) Hunting's another new thing.

The only issue I have with it is that its gotten easy for me, but this is after dozens of hours of playing it. (Once you get into a rhythm with an axe and a shotgun, zombies are less intimidating.) And it's still fun anyway. I'll gather up shotgun shells and corral zombies, because there's a certain joy to thinning out the horde while zigging and zagging between the undead. I'm looking forward to when NPCs are added back in, and for multiplayer to be improved. Overall, this is a good game that keeps getting better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I haven't played a zombie survival game quite like this. There is a constant sense of dread and fear that I don't really feel in many other games, which is probably a weird thing to put as a positive point, but trying to survive and thrive with these constant overbearing themes is quite the experience.

The field of vision system works great, in that even though it's third person you can only see zombies etc that are in the direction you are facing, making some night walks particularly tense when you can hear a zombie creeping up behind you, and turn around to see it biting your arm and making the next few hours a horrible struggle to try and stem the infection (which is pretty much hopeless, I find).

The feeling of isolation the game brings isn't even lost in the (currently very beta) multiplayer - constantly losing sight of each other in the same way as zombies made for many scary moments when we couldn't find each other. It just shows that games don't need cutting edge visuals to deliver the most authentic experience, for example Silent Hill 1 is still probably the scariest game I have ever played.

There is still a lot more to the game I haven't even tried, such as the crafting and more advanced cooking, mainly because I'm too busy being paranoid about making sure all my lights are off and curtains are closed. A favourite of mine is peering out of the curtains and accidentally locking eyes with a zombie outside, who will proceed to thump his head against your window until the dull thuds drive you insane enough to go deal with it yourself. Which you should do - it turns out they do break the windows eventually, as I so unfortunately discovered.

All in all, even in the early access state it's in the game is a great experience. I'm looking forward to seeing what's going to be added. A tenner for a game is never really a bad deal, and if you can pick it up in a sale, then it's a no-brainer. As you will soon be when the massive undead hordes get chased from the cities into your sleepy suburb. Good luck.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was put off this game for a long time due to being a graphics ♥♥♥♥♥, but I bit the bullet today and tried this, and it is awesome.

It is one of the hardest games I've played, with quite a high learning curve, but it is addictive and very well done.

I didn't like the lack of a grouping function and the aiming is pretty hardcore with guns.

Monitoring your storage and health is key, infections will riddle your body and slowly drain your health.

Crafting and Farming are also key to your survival, we found a farm out in the middle of nowhere, which had a well (SCORE FREE WATER) however we tried to figure out farming, and ended up with many rotten items.

The zombies are superhuman with bat-like hearing, and will hunt you down like the victim you are.

Recommended. 10/10 Would die of multiple infections again.

###Edit##

I'm also going to highlight the multiplayer dedicated server is terrible with multiple bugs that cannot be fixed easily, and because of that, my usual go to server company won't even support it. Only highlighting that for the fact some of you will want to run your own servers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yes its great but I'll leave tips instead of a review. Plenty of others cover the game. I'll just say this is my fav zombie game ever.

No spoilers...

1. Customize your game!
The default settings, for me, are horrible. Up XP gain, make zombies not run, up item find etc. Make it easier and modify settings before you start a new game.
Just because you find more guns and ammo doesn't mean the game gets easier. *wink*

2. Multiplayer
If you have a friend to play with even better. Played with my bro and we had a good time. Just be sure NOT to run outside the map. He took me on some very long, boring runs. Also, try not to run through forests (go around).

3. Slow Starter
You will need to learn the maps which takes a while. Enjoy the journey. Start with one map and play it over and over.

4. Mods
Lots of them. Have a lookie. I'm yet to play em so can't comment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finally my fortress is built. Now I should stockpile medicines for emergency situations. I remember a small clininc by a elementary school hmm.. I will go there in the morning.  5am very well fed and hydrated will scavange for food as I travel to clinic. 10am hungry and thirsty time to scavenge a meal. Look in windows no zeds about sounds quiet open door 3 zeds pile out$#&! Dang scratched and bleeding no bandages. Rip a sheet apply.  pain but no meds... run to clinic.. open door more zeds axe em down start looting meds for scratch aahhhh a crawler remains more damage life force running out.. shut door behind me no more sneak ups.... finally able to treat wounds and rest.  4 days of bed rest before I can travel back to fortress with medicines.  Dang I used 1/2 of the painkillers  to stay alive...was it worth it..... should I restart with thichskin or maybe faster healing... oh being a doctor would have helped I can't decide...

This game is awsome I would recomend it to anyone without a heart condition, and maybe a few jerks with hypertension.

I understand that's realistic, however, when I've already killed 1000 zeds I don't feel my character should be phased by a single little shambler not even aware of my presence until its skull is scattered across the ground... Eh, just an idea. Keep up the fantastic work!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Little do you know how much you need this game until you grab it by the reigns and try to ride it.  By golly, expect the ride of your life.

Project Zomboid pits you, a lone survivor, into a world filled with only death, depression and little hope for survival.  You are not meant to win, or survive forever - You are meant to die.  The manner in which you die, and how long it takes, it what tells your story.

This is a survival game not for the feint of heart.  It's not that it's scary, it's that it's brutal - you will die and lose, and you will learn from your mistakes - But you will love learning from your mistakes all the same.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Project Zomboid offers a lot of good things to the zombie survivalist- the main emphasis of the gameplay is almost entirely around trying to survive each day, with supplies growing scarce, the horde growing larger, in constant fear if that scratch you got from one of those zombies that jumped you when you were going through the kitchen cabinets managed to pass on their deadly disease.

Survival in Zomboid is not of course, entirely dominated by avoiding or doing battle with the infected. You must brave the elements, weather storms, sickness, boredom, panic attacks, food poisonings, food spoilage, tainted water, and trying to make do without the myriad of other everyday conveniences like refrigeration, healthcare, food and shelter.

Zomboid is also grimly fatalistic- you will die. Even the game's opening intro always ends with 'This is a story of how you died.' You may survive, but accidents, bad luck or just plain bad planning can end your life in a heartbeat. Thankfully, the game does not end with death, and you're allowed to create another character in the world, perhaps a bit wiser this time.

The game features an extensive crafting, building and farming system, already fully implemented, even 'tho the game is in EA. Latest additions also added fishing, and the game world is still growing, with new features such as character classes, new items and areas being added in a steady pace.

My only major grievance with the game is the inexplainably high ping, even on servers that are not remote from my location. I've seen pings rise from 40 ms to 1000, and on one occasion, even 18k. Hopefully, the devs can finetune the game code for servers and such in the future, allowing smoother multiplayer experiences.

So far, I've generally played on cooperative and non-hostile PvE servers- the community is nice enough, unlike on most FPS gaming communities, but not free of griefers, player killers or people abusing external voice chat to annoy others. Thankfully, the latter can always be muted, but one should be wary of players coming at you with an axe or handgun, either out of sadistic troll mentality, or interest in the contents of your backpack.

All in all, the game doesn't offer much interest in the singleplayer department as of yet- the scenarios originally released with the game involving Baldspot and his wife Kate have been removed for now, as have been the NPCs, which would have definitely added more colour to the game world. Still, supposing you can find an adequetely populated server, I guess you can set up a survivalist commune, and fight the zombies (and humans) together, bringing extra fun to the game experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Sims after the Zombie Apocalypse.

I honestly can't make it more straight forward than that.

- Eat! . . . Or be eaten.
- Sleep! or pass out in the most akward of moments.
- Work! You need income.. So better scavange and get that food on the table.
- Decorate! Paint and new furniture available at your local supermarket.
- Keep those green fingers busy. Better read up on your gardening skills before the water and power runs out.
- Get to know your neighbours. With an axe.
- Make a family. That lady down the street that you always fancied? Lure that walking corpse of a ♥♥♥♥♥ upstairs and lock her in the closet. Barricade it and make sure she stays in there!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Extremely impressive in terms of interactivity, think even Ultima 6/7 didnt have that much stuff you could do with stuff and stuff and also what stuff could do to you. Im really abit at a loss at what to list as an example.

Of course theres cooking with an extensive array of utensils and ingredients. You could drink a bottle of whiskey to get abit happier. Then you could fill that bottle with water to have something to drink when theres no toilet (yup) or sink near. Then you could put that bottle into a plastic bag you found for abit of weight reduction, but then you of course could use only one handed weapons, better to have a backpack. Then when you get hungry you could pour that water into a bowl and if you had flour you could make dough, if you had ramen you put that together and then put it into any near oven. If you dont want the zombos to disturb you you could hang some sheets on the windows and switch of the light, and read a magazine to reduce some boredom while you wait until its done. And theres lots of other interactions like that.

Combat is simple but functional, as are the graphics (abit of Postal 1 and Jagged Alliance) and controls. Inventory management/looting seems complicated at first but its really not if you get a hang of the menues.

It really seems like a waste that this great framework of interactivity is wasted on yet another fart around until you die" sandbox instead of being the basis for at least an rpg-lite with at least a few rudimentary goals. But seeing as its exactly advertised as a "fart around until you die" sandbox it delivers

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAnother true zombie survival game. Its made in a 2d style of a game and its suppose to look old. The gameplay is how a zombie survival game should be like. You start off in a home. All you gotta do now is survive but you gotta get food and protect yourself. After a couple of years in game eventually electricty will shut off forcing all fridge food to go bad, this will soon lead you to making a garden. After another couple of years water will shut off so now you are forced to get water from rivers/ponds. Making loud noises such as shooting in cities will prob lead to death send hundreds of zombies to you

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The User Interface's a mess, the game is extremely crash prone, it's a performance killer, and there's not much content.

But, it's more engrossing and open-ended than State of Decay, and you don't have to immediately deal with psychopathic survivors who want you dead when you start, unlike DayZ (at least, until human NPCs are implemented, or online multiplayer's added)

If you're willing to accept that it's an Early Access title, get this. If not, wait a few more months, and then get it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tl;dr version, 8.5/10, still has a ways to go but as it is one of the most intense and realistic zombie survival games in a genre cluttered by easy fixes.

There was no happy ending. This is how you died.

I've been keeping up with Zomboid for longer than I'd like to think about. When it was first announced and gathering attention, the gaming world was abuzz with a zombie survival game the likes of which we had never really seen done well. The initial game they pumped out was fun and the promises of the game to come sounded like a dream come true for hardcore gamers.

But as time went on, I lost interest due to slow updates. The game kept progressing, and every year or so I'd check up on it. I was generally impressed, but eventually just felt like there were enough zombie survival games emerging like Dayz that Project Zomboid had lost its chance. Finally, I decided to check its progress out one last time.

And I was finally hooked.

The experience it delivers is one that no other games to date have really offered. This is a true zombie survival horror game. It does not about action. It is not forgiving. You are thrust in the middle of a zombie apocalpyse with nothing but the clothes on your back and must survive any way you can for as long as you can. There is no happy ending here. The game only gets harder, and you will eventually die.

You create your character picking a profession and using a beneficial/detrimental perk point system, meaning if you want your character to be strong you will have to give something up, such as asmtha or illiteracy. There are tough choices to be made, and many skills that are very useful. There are skills for cooking, gardening, foraging, and of course combat, and you are unlikely to get many of them very high unless you survive a long time. You will have to specialize your character.

If you leave your oven on, it will burn your house to the ground. But maybe that's a good thing as you lured a horde of zombies to a house far from your safehouse and incinerated them all inside. The simple act of climbing through a broken window can give you an infection leading to death if you are not slow and careful. Running is taboo. Fighting every zombie is a chance of being bit and dead.

The music is good ambient music that will set the mood, from a quiet slow terror to a banging intense beat if you are running from a herd. The sounds are functional and also quite terrifying. The graphics look nice while being low enough to be able to handle hundreds of zombies on screen and hundreds more off screen lumbering around. One thing that is not as functional is the animations, most of which are decent but I feel the game could use more of them to make things more clear in a game where there is no room for error.

The game gives you a great amount of customization for your gaming experience, and you can start on a good beginner difficulty to learn how to survive in a safer enviroment or pump up the zombies from Dawn of the Dead to 28 Days Later fast and die quicker. Multiplayer is offered, but at the time of this writing has a long way to go to being something amazing. The potential is there and there are some great encounters to be had with some friends but public servers seem to still be off.

This game is slow to move, but the developers are good about paying attention to the community and I have faith that if/when they finally deliver this game to it's full form, it will be the definitive zombie survival experience.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Project zomboid was well worth the money, It has slowly been evolving and with each new iteration it gets just a little bit better. Updates are slow, but they do come.

If you enjoy survival situations and zombies you'll like this game.

I've had it since long before it's steam release, and it has indeed come a long way. As with everyone else I await the arrival of NPC characters with baited breath. I'll come back and write a real review then.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Project Zomboid
Genre:
Horror, Survival, RPG, Action, (Dying Simulator)

Out of 10 what score would you give it?
I would give it  10/10  due to being a unique and different style of the overused zombie survival genre.

Brief description of the gameplay:
Project Zomboid is an isometric 2.5-D (A 2D image that simulates depth much like 3D) zombie survival game that is very much different from all of the other...generic zombie games, including a realistic medical system in which you MUST keep an eye on your wounds else you might not wake up the next morning!

What was good about this game?
Everything! I mean from the configurable settings to the weather and the amount of things you can do in the game, looking after yourself is vital to your survival from depression and boredom to stress & temperature, every aspect of the human condition is counted as a survival mechanism and for you to truly survive & thrive in this environment you must manage all of this effectively, failure to do so results in death, and not just you die

*Right click to charge your swing and to sneak...it's easier(don't try to use the cntrl button)

*Lose the zeds by going around the trees etc(line of sight)

*Fiind a safehouse and clear out the zeds in your area 1-2 at a time

*Fill up all your pots/cups/bottles etc with water from the faucet early in game

*Find an Axe!!!

*Survive and HAVE FUN!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have played this game A TON. And I have to say, I do get a little bored everynow and then, this is usually remedied by actually going outside IRL and playing in the woods. Seems Legit.

THIS IS THE BEST ZOMBIE GAME EVER. I was surfing steam and saw some bad reviews on another game and I wondered if this game had any bad revies ( I want to play some PZ now so Ill be quick-ish). There are a few bad reviews for this game, but if you take the time to actually play the game then read through the reviews:

A: They are all rage reviews
B: They are all rage reviews
C: They are all rage reviews

Its that simple...

PZ is a game where you survive a zombie apocalypse, seems simple ; but after falling out of a window and breaking your leg, then getting eaten by zombies trying to get to a clinic, you will realise this game is not for the faint of heart. If you are serious about surviving, this game is for you. I have spent 30+ hours playing and have yet to see the power/water to go out. This can make the game seem redundent. Ask your friends what their plans are for the ZApocalypse and try it out.

Not only is this game deep and makes your work to get anywhere, it shows alot of promise. Although it has been in Early Access for ALONG TIME, this has no effect on how fun the game is, in fact it just shows the devs are devicated" (insert facepalm here). With talk of NPC's and cars
date: it's only a matter of time until I will be playing PZ 24/7. I love this game.\n\nMy only issue would be that the game gets a bit redundent. But that only really happens when you try to live in the same house 7 playthroughs straight. Trust me
recommended: dont do that. If you want an interesting challenge
hoursPlayed: make a charecter that you know from a book or TV series. Make sure to put in all of their negatives and positives - Example: Shane from TWD. Im not going to list out all of the traits because this is already long but :P. I spent the part of the 50$ steam card I got to buy KSP on this game. Why? I still don't know. The graphics arent the greatest and all of that
voteText:
but this game is great.

10/10 would recommend this again.

Edit: There are mods that add rediculous amount of extra stuff to do :P"
